TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson, is attending a funeral today and will be absent from the chamber during Question Time. Questions normally directed to Senator Richardson should be addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, Senator Collins.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I ask: has the Government made any estimate of the number of casualties likely to be suffered by Australian peacekeepers in the course of their deployment in Cambodia? If so, what percentage figure has been assessed, and was any assessment made prior to the current escalation of fighting in Cambodia?

—The Department of Defence has made no such estimate as Senator Durack suggests. But what we have quite clearly done, and I think I have put it on the record before, is list the potential dangers that any Australian service men and women would face in Cambodia. Probably the number one danger is in the hygiene area. There are numerous strands of disease, unfortunately, in that country at the moment. One of the main reasons why the UN and Australia favour the military option is the discipline usually shown by troops in looking after their own hygiene and their surrounds. There is always a danger, in a country such as Cambodia, of mines. No-one knows how many millions of mines there are in Cambodia. It is absolutely essential that the corporate knowledge that remains in Cambodia can be passed on by the various factions so de-mining operations can occur. There will always be a potential danger from warring factions within Cambodia.

PARA.TAB: But, as Senator Evans explained to Senator Durack yesterday, this is a peacekeeping, not a peace enforcement, operation. We do not expect this operation to unduly place any of the UN participants in danger. That cannot be guaranteed, but it would be pointless at this stage to do the exercise of estimating the number of casualties, as Senator Durack may be suggesting we do. We are anticipating no casualties. We are hoping for no casualties, but we can give no guarantee that there will not be some casualties.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the Minister aware of proposals to contract out and privatise services currently provided by the Department of Administrative Services? Can the Minister indicate whether there are savings to be made to revenue through such proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen recent proposals to contract out, as well as to privatise, functions of the Department of Administrative Services. They were part of the Opposition's consumption tax package and they were released last November.

PARA.TAB: Since that time, I have been sitting back here waiting for questions from the Opposition in respect of those proposals. I thought that Senator Parer, at least, would have liked to pursue the case. But I have had no questions, and it is quite apparent why not.

The savings estimated by the Opposition in this area are wrong on three grounds, and they are wrong to the tune of $500m over the first three years of the package. There are anticipated savings of $540m—$500m wrong. There is a $500m black hole in the GST package. It is a discrepancy caused by incompetence, lack of understanding and a basic inability to count. The Opposition policies in this area are based on the work of a Professor Domberger. Domberger states:

ANSWER.PARA: It is the introduction of competition, rather than awarding contracts to private firms, which is the critical cost-saving factor.

The Opposition uses this principle and decides not to contract out, but to privatise functions. It says that privatising is the only way. The Opposition is working on the wrong premise. It is competition that leads to savings, not the act of privatising. The Opposition has misapplied Domberger's findings, but that is not the full extent of its blunder. Its analysis ignores one basic development. Since 1987, the Government has radically restructured the Department of Administrative Services. As Domberger says, it is competition that leads to savings. We have introduced competition. We have had it for at least four years. Fifty per cent of the functions of Administrative Services are now untied and, through decisions already taken, by the next financial year 90 per cent of value-added of the Department of Administrative Services will be untied and open to competition.

PARA.TAB: We have already achieved the savings. We are already saving $200m per annum; productivity has been increasing at 5 per cent since 1987. So it is no wonder that the Department of Finance could not support the Opposition's calculations. It is no wonder that it could find only $35m worth of savings in this area as opposed to the Opposition's anticipated savings of $540m.

Not only has the Opposition got it wrong twice; it has got it wrong three times, and there is a doozey involved in this. The Opposition got its details wrong. Without going into all of them, let me instance just one to show the Senate and the Australian people the extent of the incompetence in this area. In the consumption tax package, the Opposition has made the claim that through contracting out the services of the Overseas Property Group there will be savings of $20m per annum. This shows amazing ineptitude. The OPG has a budget of $130m for 1991-92, so the Opposition assumes that 20 per cent of that is close to $20m and that it can realise that sort of saving through contracting out the functions—and that is what the Opposition has whacked into its document.

But OPG's running costs are only $3m out of $130m. The rest of it is already contracted out to the private sector; it includes rents, construction fit-outs and so on. All but $3m of OPG's budget is already contracted out. So we have this fantastic claim that, out of a budget of $3m, it can save $20m. It is embarrassingly wrong for the Opposition.

There has been no homework. There has been no application to the task, no attempt to understand the programs it plans to contract out, just an inept application of ideology with no serious policy work. Its opposition to DAS illustrates the general approach in the Fightback package. It is a lazy retreat to ideology—unsupported assertions, rather than hard policy work.
The Opposition should, given this example, know all the pitfalls in contracting out. It contracted out the analysis for its Fightback document and look at the mess it got itself into.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Air Traffic Control System at Cairns Airport

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation aware of serious allegations made in an article in the Townsville Bulletin today that the Cairns Airport radar system is placing lives at risk?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statements are serious and grossly irresponsible. They have been made by Senator Bill O'Chee, who opened his press release with the following words:

ANSWER.PARA: The Civil Aviation Authority. . . has been summonsed to appear before the Senate Estimates Committee. . . by Far Northern Senator Bill O'Chee.
`Far-out Senator Bill O'Chee' would be closer to the mark.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. If Senator Collins wishes to quote from documents, perhaps he ought to quote from documents that actually exist and not newspaper stories and attribute them to my press releases.
—There is no point of order. I cannot verify the document that Senator Collins is quoting from.

—I am delighted that Senator O'Chee has so quickly been embarrassed by what he has told the Townsville Bulletin. I would be very anxious to have some assurance from Senator O'Chee after Question Time that, in fact, he said none of this. He went on to simply assert that the Thomson radar system at Cairns was `substandard'.
—It is.

—I am glad he has reaffirmed that. He said that lives were at risk and then went on to castigate the Civil Aviation Authority for not answering 17 detailed questions he had put to it. He is quoted as saying this about those questions:

PARA.TAB: I'm as angry as hell that they haven't answered my questions and they had better have some answers tomorrow night.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator O'Chee put these questions in a week ago. The CAA does, in fact, have a few things to do, like running safety regulation in Australia, rather than running around giving instant responses to detailed questions. I understand that I will have the answers to the questions this afternoon prior to Estimates hearings.

PARA.TAB: This is mischievous stuff. It is designed to attempt to create—and deliberately create—the impression that the CAA is not prepared to answer the questions. This is the second time this week that Senator O'Chee has issued such a mischievous and misleading press release. It does him no credit at all. I can do no better than to quote the executive secretary of Civil Air—that is, the air traffic controllers' union—on the radar system, who, when he was asked on the ABC on 20 March whether the current system was safe, said, `The system is safe'. When he was asked whether the new system was safe, the response was, `It is also safe'.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it isn't.

—If Senator Macdonald wants to contradict the air traffic controllers, he can go ahead. Just to indicate how mischievous and false these very irresponsible claims are—and they are very similar to the tirade of statements that Senator Schacht and I became so familiar with issued by Senator MacGibbon during the pilots strike, all of which proved to be groundless—the incident is then quoted in the Townsville Bulletin involving the F28 flying into Cairns which did not appear on the radar.

PARA.TAB: I have already stated in Question Time this week for Senator O'Chee's benefit—and it was lost on him because he is obviously not interested in the truth of this issue—that on investigation it was discovered that the problem with the F28 was a faulty radar transponder on board the aircraft, and it had nothing whatever to do with the system itself. Despite that, the CAA is double checking the system, as it always does, by running actual test flights at Cairns to ensure that the problem was, in fact, with the transponder and not with the system.

The fact is that software problems are a feature of any air traffic control system in the world. All air traffic controllers in the world, including Australian air traffic controllers, are trained to deal with those eventualities efficiently. There are efficient backup systems in place to deal with these occasional problems. They are employed in Cairns. The system in Cairns is not substandard; it is perfectly safe; and Senator O'Chee should withdraw these mischievous and very irresponsible statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. To say that a senator is obviously not interested in the truth of a matter I would suggest to you reflects upon that senator. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Costs of Production of Goods and Services

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Minister recognise that, for the proper operation of the market mechanism in the allocation of resources, prices of goods and services must include the full cost of manufacture? Does the Minister also recognise that many of the costs of production of goods and services are external to the direct manufacturing costs and have been called by economists `externalities', and that economists and those who defend the market as an efficient allocator of resources argue for the internalisation of those externalities? Does the Minister recognise that the market will only work if these externalities are internalised and what mechanisms has the Government adopted to achieve this end? Is sales tax a useful instrument for this purpose and how would the adoption of a GST interfere with this role?

—The honourable senator has really asked me for a legal opinion on which, I suppose, I am not fit to provide an answer. I do not want to get into a theoretical debate. Any tax which is imposed on the output of production is, of course, detrimental to that process. A GST falls into that category, as does a wholesale sales tax.
—Not if it is fully rebated on inputs.
—It is only rebatable in respect of export activity and—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I took that to be the point of Senator Coulter's question, because he asked me about it.
—You don't understand the basis of the GST.
—Of course I understand the basis of the GST. I understand how it cascades through every level of production. I cannot answer Senator Coulter's question because I do not quite understand it.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The point of order I want to raise with you is a point on which you have ruled on many occasions. You have said that a Minister may only refer to the part of the question which relates to the Government's policy and his own portfolio. Clearly, the Minister struggles trying to understand anything that is outside his portfolio and gets it wrong frequently. I would ask you, Mr President, to uphold your previous rulings. If not, would you explain to us how the ruling would differentiate from your previous rulings?
—There is no point of order.

—I was concerned about the highly theoretical terms in which Senator Coulter phrased his question. Of course, the supplementary question will be about whether the externalities to which he refers include environmental considerations. I do not know the answer to that question. I will try to get Senator Coulter an answer from the appropriate Minister.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The supplementary question is not as the Minister indicated. I am surprised that Senator Button, as one who has so extolled the virtues of the market, does not understand that we are talking in economic terms and not legal terms. Perhaps the Minister would care to define what he and many of his colleagues have called externalities in this common jargon among economists.

—In a range of economic considerations, externalities are defined by economists as a whole range of things beyond the scope of the productive process. In terms of production, externalities include all the cost structures which bear on the production process.

—Does the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce agree with the claim made by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, on 14 March last year that the textile, clothing and footwear and motor vehicle industries were having a loaf behind the tariff walls? Does the Minister also agree with the Prime Minister when he said that if they are non-competitive and can never be competitive, frankly, we would be better off without them; and further that protection was a monkey on the back of every exporter? In view of the Prime Minister's selective back-flip on tariffs—which the Prime Minister justified by saying that quantitative restrictions limited world trade in textiles, clothing, footwear and cars—in the interests of consistency, what does the Minister say to those industries which claim protection for the sugar, cheese, fruit and other agricultural commodities where similar, more corrupt, world markets exist?

—Firstly, 14 March 1991 seems to have been a field day for people talking about the statement which was made on 12 March. The 12 March 1991 statement laid down the policy of this Government on tariffs. It is very clear, and there is no mistake about that policy and what it is intended to do.

PARA.TAB: In so far as Mr Keating might have said that industries had loafed behind tariff walls, that is a view which I would regard as impeccable. I would regard that as true of most Australian industries which were highly protected throughout the period of Liberal conservative governments during the 1960s and the 1970s. I believe that they loafed behind tariff walls and the Opposition encouraged loafers throughout that period when it was in government. I agree with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about the President of the ACTU?

—It is all very well for Senator Panizza to interject about the President of the ACTU. What about the Minister who held my portfolio. When advised by the Industries Assistance Commission in 1978 to have a general reduction in tariffs, he walked away from it saying, `There is no way that we will embark on a general reduction in tariffs'. There was no way he would do that. It is all very well to chat about the President of the ACTU, but what about the Minister in the Government at the time who walked away from all those issues?

PARA.TAB: With respect to the expression `protection is a monkey on the back of Australian industry', that was true in the past and is why we have sought to change this and have done something about it. That is distinct from the actions of the Opposition, which for many years succoured loafers by its policies on these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an insult to secondary industry.

—Senator Boswell describes that as an insult. As Senator Macdonald well knows, there are differences of opinion within the coalition about agricultural protection. Senator Boswell goes around Queensland bagging this Government because the tariff on sugar will be reduced in July this year from $76 a tonne to $50 a tonne—or whatever the exact figure is—but he does not for a moment tell the people of Queensland what is in the Fightback policy. He does not say that there will be a zero tariff on agricultural production. He does not tell them that. He talks with a forked tongue about these particular issues when in Queensland, as do other Opposition senators. As at July next year the tariff level for sugar will be equivalent to a 27 per cent tariff, but the coalition is going to get rid of that. Senator Macdonald should be telling people in Queensland that that is what he is going to do, and Senator Boswell should say that as well.
—And slash the cost of production. Why are you not honest enough to say so?

—Senator Baume keeps interjecting about slashing the cost of production. The magic wand experts—Hewson and McLachlan—are going to come in and create an environment in this country which has been created in no other country in the world. In no other country in the world—not in Margaret Thatcher's England—has there been a policy of zero industry protection. That has not been adopted by any developed country.
—How about the Asian trading partners?

—No country in the developed world lacks a policy for protecting its motor vehicle and textiles, clothing and footwear industries. Senator Bishop ought to understand that before she interjects. That will be the same throughout the 1990s because that is what is being talked about in the Uruguay Round. For God's sake, Senator Macdonald should not come in here asking these questions about the Opposition's policies until he is prepared to explain them honestly to the people of Queensland.

—I ask a supplementary question. The question was not about our policies, and I would not have asked the Minister about them. The Minister has proved that he cannot even read the Fightback document. My question was about the Government's policies and, no doubt because of the Wills by-election, the Minister skilfully avoided answering it. The Government has done a backflip on Wills with respect to textiles, clothing and footwear and motor vehicles. Is the Government going to do the same backflip with respect to cheese, fruit, sugar and other agricultural commodities?
—The policy in respect of sugar was announced in the March 1991 statement—
—And has not changed.
—The matter has been referred to the Industries Commission, which is the normal course we follow, but it has not been changed.
—If you are changing on TCF, why are you not changing on the others?

—The premise of the question is that we are changing on TCF. That is not so. We are not changing on TCF. The Opposition is trying to say that there is no difference between the Government and the coalition—and Dr Hewson said this last week—on tariff policy. That is what he said last week. Those opposite chose the date of 14 March. On 14 March last year Dr Hewson said, `The Government has come halfway towards the Opposition's policies on tariffs but it has not gone far enough'. That is what he said.
—Mr Keating even said you were wrong.

—I am trying to answer Senator Macdonald's question. With respect to agricultural commodities, the position is quite clearly stated. I have clearly stated that position in relation to sugar. There are certain quotas on cheese at the present time. I am not able to tell the Opposition off the cuff when those quotas expire. In each case, these matters are referred to the Industry Commission and, generally, the Government adopts the Industry Commission's report.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to recent overseas reports that North Korea is about to become a nuclear power. Does the Minister believe that this could possibly destabilise the west Pacific region? Further, would such a development have any impact on Australia?

—I am familiar with reports to which Senator Maguire refers. The most dramatic of them, I guess, was the testimony of the Director of the CIA, Robert Gates, before the United States Senate last month. I need hardly say that this is an issue which my Department and the intelligence community in this country have been following extremely closely for some time.

PARA.TAB: We have been very deeply concerned by the evidence of substantial, unsafeguarded nuclear facilities in North Korea which could, indeed, be intended for a nuclear weapons program. Assessments vary as to how long it would take North Korea to become a nuclear weapons state, if that is indeed the country's intention. But a worse case scenario, which Mr Gates, for example, was outlining, is one which could have North Korea a nuclear weapons state within a very short space of time—indeed, a matter of months rather than years.

We would, of course, regard such a development as fundamentally destabilising in the Asia-Pacific region and, indeed, as the most serious security threat in our region. Our judgment is shared by nearly all of our friends and allies, with whom we have been making vigorous attempts to persuade the DPRK not to pursue such a course. Our concerns have been put very directly and in strong terms to DPRK Ministers and officials. We have worked very hard with others such as Japan and the US to register this message. We have also impressed on countries which have close links with the DPRK, such as China, the dramatic security implications of such a development. It is in fact the case that all major powers in the region, including China, Russia and Japan, have made clear that they are opposed to a North Korean nuclear weapons capability.

I think it has been generally acknowledged that Australia has been very active on this issue, indeed at the forefront of efforts within the International Atomic Energy Agency, to have the DPRK ratify and implement the safeguards agreement that it signed on 30 January this year, as required by its accession back in 1985 to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Implementation of that would bring with it IAEA inspections, which are essential to the verification of North Korea's intentions with its nuclear program. The DPRK's signature of a safeguards agreement and its bilateral agreements with South Korea have been very welcome signs of progress on the Korean Peninsula generally. But we, I have to say, are very far from confident of the DPRK's intentions on unconditional implementation, particularly in view of the country's past record.

I take this further opportunity, in the strongest possible terms, to urge North Korea to quickly allow International Atomic Energy Agency inspections and to therefore allay the concerns which are very widespread in the international community about its nuclear intentions. If the international community cannot be reassured in this way, we will be faced with a very serious situation indeed in which further measures will need to be considered. For obvious reasons, I do not want to canvass what those measures might be—that will be a matter for the international community as a whole. I hope very much indeed that it will not come to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the report in the Australian of 17 March 1992 that he threatened the Confederation of Australian Industry with right to strike legislation. Will the Government be introducing right to strike amendments to the Industrial Relations Act?

—This is a weird question emanating from Senator Crane. What I was commenting on in that article is a matter that the Confederation of Australian Industry has referred to the International Labour Organisation under freedom of association convention 87. The matter that has been referred is that the minimum size, as prescribed in our legislation, for a federally registered union in Australia should be 10,000. The Confederation's contention is that that goes against freedom of association as laid down by the United Nations International Labour Organisation, the ILO. Of course, our contention is nothing of the sort, but the matter is being dealt with in the forum of the ILO.

PARA.TAB: My observation was that the committee of experts of the ILO—a body of 20 judges, eminent judges at High Court level in Australia or higher, from a representative political spectrum of countries and a geographically balanced spectrum of countries—has held that domestic Australian law is in contravention of the very same convention that the Confederation now wishes to argue ought to be upheld in its view, that is, the convention on freedom of association.

What I was saying in that interview was that if the case of the Confederation—and, I might say, this is a very big `if'—were to succeed, we would feel bound to conform with the convention. Australia is a country which observes international standards and we believe other countries should, too. We would feel obliged to conform to the convention. But we would not conform to the convention in simply the case that suited the Confederation; we would conform in all cases.

In the case dealing with the findings of the committee of experts, we would have to consider conforming to the convention. In short, what we were saying is that if one invokes international labour standards, as is one's right, and demands that the government observe them, the government should observe them. We do observe them, but we should observe them fiercely and not pick favourites in terms of which particular parts of those conventions are observed or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trades. I draw the Minister's attention to reports of the killing of at least 30 people in the past few days in the border region between Bosnia and Croatia and the threat by the Yugoslavian Government to intervene and defend Serbs in Bosnia-Herzegovinia. With the pending deployment next month of 14,000 members of the United Nations peacekeeping force, I ask: does the Minister believe that the latest fighting, together with the Yugoslavian Army's threat, will cause a delay in the deployment of UN troops or put in doubt the negotiated truce agreed to last January?

—The recent reports of fighting in and around the UN protected areas in Croatia are of serious concern in the context of the impending full deployment of UNPROFOR, or UN Protection Force, expected this coming month, in April. There have already been several exchanges of artillery fire which have landed near UNPROFOR personnel. There are clearly grounds for concern that the current escalation of violent incidents in Croatia could lead to a breakdown of the cease-fire that has generally held since early this year.

PARA.TAB: Against this background the force commander, Lieutenant-General Satish Nambiar, has issued an urgent appeal to the authorities in Belgrade and Zagreb to take all necessary measures to end the cease-fire violations. He added that the continuing violations `needlessly prolonged' the suffering of the civilian population and could delay the full deployment of the force. There is also an obvious danger that fighting will intensify in the neighbouring republic of Bosnia-Herzegovinia where delicate negotiations on that republic's future are now under way.

Australia, along with the rest of the international community, is insisting that the parties to the conflict, including the Yugoslav Army, act in a moderate and rational manner to enable all the issues to be resolved peacefully. The international community has put in place the necessary structures in the form of UNPROFOR and the European Community's peace conference, chaired by Lord Carrington, to allow for the peace to be kept and for a political solution to be found. We as a government have strongly supported a UN role in Yugoslavia, and we do urge all the parties involved to abide by the cease-fire arrangements so that the deployment of UNPROFOR can continue on track.

We also recognise that the safety of UN personnel in Yugoslavia is the responsibility of the force commander, as elsewhere with peace keeping operations, and the decision on how quickly he can deploy the full force will depend on his assessment of the situation on the ground. Obviously, he will not want to put his troops at undue risk. We have always recognised that UNPROFOR would have a difficult task in Yugoslavia, but we do not expect that these incidents will prevent implementation, eventually, of the UN peacekeeping plan.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to Senator Collins in his capacity as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia and, probably more importantly, as State President of the Northern Territory Labor Party. Is the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs flying in the face of advice from the Northern Territory Government and the Northern Territory Labor Opposition by issuing stop-work declarations under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act in respect of the lifesaving flood mitigation dam for Alice Springs? Will the issue of a permanent stop-work declaration, as now threatened by Minister Tickner, be inconsistent with the decision making processes adopted by Federal and Western Australian Labor governments in respect of recent projects at Yakabindie and Marandoo? How does Senator Collins reconcile the differences between his Labor colleagues in Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Canberra; and will he guarantee that the actions taken by Mr Tickner will not jeopardise his constituents' lives and property?

—Could I make it clear immediately that I will not be answering this question in my capacity as President of the Labor Party in the Northern Territory. But I will answer the question. Senator Tambling asked me whether the actions of the Northern Territory Government are inconsistent with or contradictory to the positions taken by Western Australian governments, and so on. What in fact is the case is that the actions of the Northern Territory Government are absolutely contradictory to the advice it is receiving under its own legislation from its own Sacred Sites Protection Authority. That is a matter of public fact, and that is what makes the Northern Territory Government's current position very difficult to sustain.

PARA.TAB: The Northern Territory Parliament enacted—and I was there when it happened—its own legislation to protect Aboriginal sacred sites. The advice that has been given to the Northern Territory Government by its own Sacred Sites Protection Authority, under that Act, is not to go ahead with this dam. That is the question initially that I would have thought Senator Tambling might have liked to address some attention to.

What is sadly needed and badly needed in this whole debate about the important question of flood mitigation for Alice Springs—and it is important—is that all of the parties to this debate cool off. It does not assist the debate in a rational way for the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory to issue public statements saying that not only will the dam proceed, but that the Northern Territory Government's gaols are big enough to gaol anybody who tries to stop it. The debate is not helped by Northern Territory Government Ministers swapping abuse with people at public meetings in Alice Springs and telling Aboriginal people to get off their bums and solve their grog problems. The debate is not helped by the Northern Territory Government placing Wormald private security guards at a gate and denying Aboriginal people access to their own sacred sites.

I believe that the actions that have been taken by the Federal Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs are precisely what should have happened—that is, a report is going to be called for under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act, which he administers. The period of time that will elapse will give everybody a chance to cool off and have a little more rational attitude towards this issue. As a result, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs will be in a position to get some independent engineering advice as to whether the engineering options that have been proposed for this dam are viable or are not viable. That is the way it should be resolved. I totally support the actions that the Minister has taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am well aware that Senator Collins has counselled everybody to cool off and back off and not get emotional or irrational. Perhaps he should take some of that advice himself. TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 March Senator Reid asked me a question relating to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. The response required a great deal of detail. I obtained an answer from the Minister for Finance which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
In a question without notice on 26th March concerning the performance of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme Senator Reid asked me. . .

"Why is it that the effective annual rate of interest paid on contributions to the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme through the Retirement Benefits Office during 1990-91 was only 2.84 per cent? How does the Government explain such a poor return, given that most large superannuation funds outside the Government earned between 9 and 18 per cent over the same period?
I undertook to consult the Minister for Finance who has provided the following response.

Responsibility for the investment Commonwealth Superannuation Fund lies, of course, not with the Minister for Finance or the Retirement Benefits Office, but with the Board of Trustees of the Fund. However, this is not the first occasion that the question of the Fund's 1990-91 results has been raised and I am informed that the following is the form of the response provided by the Board in respect of similar queries.

"Clearly the recent performance of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund has been disappointing but on the more positive side the returns achieved by the Fund for the first two quarters of this current financial year have been strongly positive with annualised fund earning rates of 9.6% and 13.9% being achieved for the September and December quarters.

When considering the performance of a Superannuation Fund it is important to recognise that superannuation is a long term investment. Therefore, the primary objective is to maximise the expected rate of returns over long term while investing safely. It can sometimes be very difficult to achieve this objective and at the same time maintain acceptable short term returns.

In an effort to achieve these objectives a balanced approach to investment of the Fund is being pursued. Under this approach the Fund is invested in most major investment sectors such as shares, property, fixed interest etc. This approach has earned relatively good returns for Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme (CSS) contributors in the long term. Indeed for the 5 years to 30 June 1991 the Fund's interest allocation rate has averaged 11.03 per cent per annum notwithstanding the stockmarket crash in October 1987 and the disappointing returns achieved in 1990/91.

At the commencement of the 1990-91 financial year over 35% of the Fund's assets were held in property. This had reduced to 29.9% by the end of the calendar year. The scheme's funds manager (Commonwealth Funds Management Limited—CFM) has reported that the disappointing performance for 1990-91 was caused by the significant downturn in the property sector and, to a lesser extent, by poor returns from the international equities sector. As you will be aware, the property sector particularly hard hit by the recession and, coupled with the Fund's relatively high exposure, was the major factor contributing to the disappointing result over all.

To make valid comparisons with the 1990-91 performance of other large funds, it would be necessary to focus on their exposure to the public sector. In this regard other large funds with significant property exposures experienced similarly disappointing results in 1990-91.

Property is by its nature an illiquid asset class and the current property market in Australia is very depressed. Nonetheless, every reasonable effort is being made to reduce the Fund's exposure to property through orderly sales at satisfactory prices. In this regard it is recognised that it would not be in the long term best interests of scheme members to conduct a "fire sale" simply to reduce exposure. Consequently, guidelines for property sales have been set which concentrate on the prospective returns which can be expected from particular properties as opposed to returns which have been achieved in the past. In addition the current overweighted exposure to property can be expected to be diluted to some extent by growth in the size of the fund contributions.

Since assuming responsibilities for the management and investment of the Fund on 1 July 1990 the new Board of Trustees has been actively involved, in consultation with an independent firm of investment advisers, in the development of a revised long term investment strategy for the Fund. That strategy will concentrate on the unique nature of the CSS Fund and the underlying nature of the liabilities it supports and will also address strategies for reducing the current negative impact of the property portfolio of overall fund performance.
Details of this new strategy will be distributed by the Board to all members once the consultation process with relevant employer and union groups has been completed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March Senator Hill asked me, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, a question relating to the Government's intentions on youth wages. I have obtained a somewhat detailed answer and I seek leave to have that incorporated in Hansard.

Senator Button—On 24 March (Hansard, page 918) Senator Hill asked me as the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question without notice about the Government's intentions to improve the skills and career prospects for young Australians through the reform of entry-level training and youth wages. He also asked what the Government means by `youth wages'. I undertook to obtain an answer for Senator Hill.
The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
At present, youth wages generally comprise award payments to persons under 21 years of age who are paid either junior rates, apprenticeship rates or Australian Traineeship System rates.

The question of youth wages and their relationship to the present system of entry-level training, largely involving apprenticeships and traineeships, is one of the issues addressed in a recent report presented to the Government by the Employment and Skills Formation Council chaired by Mr Laurie Carmichael. This report is in response to the Government's concern about the present system's ability to deliver the quantity and quality of vocational education and training necessary for a highly skilled Australian work force.

The Council proposes an Australian Vocational Certificate Training System involving a move from time-serving to competency-based training and greater delivery flexibility. Industry would be expected to substantially increase its number of work-based training places, including sectors which currently have no entry-level training arrangements. Commonwealth subsidies to employers for work-based training are recommended to continue until the 1993-94 Budget, and then extended to all industry sectors, at a lower rate per trainee. In relation to wages for trainees, the Council believes these are best determined by the industrial parties and recommends that they be based on competencies and time spent in productive work, unlike present age related time served arrangements. Where youth wages fall below the Government's standard allowance rate for 18 year old independent persons, the Council proposes a "top up" allowance to be paid by the Commonwealth, but separate from AUSTUDY.

The Government is committed to reforming entry-level training arrangements and is preparing a response to the report. The Ministers for Employment, Education and Training, and Industrial Relations are looking at the question of trainee wages, and will be consulting the States and key players over the next 2 to 3 months.

As a result of this Government funded voluntary redundancy program for meat inspectors, the number of 1654 stated by Senator Brownhill has been reduced to 1535 as at 31 March 1992 and further reductions are expected before the end of the financial year through further offers of voluntary redundancy. Overall inspection numbers have been reduced by some 373 through a planned program of voluntary redundancy since 1989 with approval for a further 170 by the end of this financial year. With particular regard to overheadquartered staff, the Food Standards Officer Award Restructuring package endorsed by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in October 1991 provides for a wide range of measures to be put in place which greatly increases flexibility in the conditions for the provision of meat inspection to abattoirs and will enable a more rapid response to reheadquartering inspectors to where they are required. This in effect means that ultimately, there will be no inspection staff remaining at locations where abattoirs have closed. I would like to point out that whilst there have been a number of meat inspectors stationed at closed headquarters, they have in fact, continued to be productively utilised as relief pool inspectors at other abattoirs.

Let me now turn to action taken by the Government to reduce the administrative costs of AQIS. In December 1990, the Minister for Resources engaged the services of management consultants Ernst and Young to review and report on the organisational form and management of AQIS. As a result of this and other intensive reviews of AQIS, in November 1991 the Minister for Resources announced a package of significant reforms, the major thrust of which was to make AQIS more business-like. Since the announcement of the package, AQIS Central Office realised immediate staff savings of 22 with a further 12-15 expected through voluntary redundancy before the end of the 1991/92 financial year. In addition to Central Office savings, the Regional Offices have also undergone reviews since 1990 which saw the closure of the Northern Territory and Tasmanian Regional offices with savings of two and ten respectively and savings of up to a total of 40 across other Regional Offices, and these reviews are still continuing. In addition, AQIS will be assisted in its endeavour to become a more commercially oriented enterprise by adopting commercial accounting procedures and the establishment of a Group 2 Trust Account on 1 July 1993 into which cost recovery revenues will be paid and from which expenditure will be funded. On July 1 1993 AQIS, will be entirely self funding in its program delivery.

Senator Newman asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, without notice, on 26 March 1992:

". . . when the annual cost of osteoporosis to the health budget is between $200m and $500m a year, why is the Federal Labor Government, after all this long time, still not prepared to extend Medicare benefits to menopausal women for densitometry as a preventive health measure?
Senator Tate—The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the Honourable Senator's question:
Bone densitometry is a high cost high-tech test for measuring the amount of minerals in bone.
It is being promoted to screen for developing osteoporosis among women during and after menopause and there is increasing public pressure to provide medicare benefits for bone densitometry.
Bone densitometry is not rebatable for two very good reasons:
there is no conclusive evidence that low bone mineral content is a good predictor of increased risk of fracture, the major health problem resulting from osteoporosis; and
there is no consensus amongst the medical profession on an effective treatment for people with low bone mineral content in the middle and older age groups.
The Government's decision not to provide a rebate was taken on advice from the medical profession through the Medicare Advisory Committee.
The Opposition's proposals for bone densitometry screening have a number of problems:
they focus only on the diagnosis of osteoporosis and ignore the important issues of prevention and treatment;
they focus on women and do not recognise osteoporosis as a health problem associated with ageing and therefore of concern to Australian men as well; and
the $8 million per annum quoted by the Opposition is a significant under estimate HHCS considers a more realistic cost to be of the order of $50m per annum.
The Government aims to develop a comprehensive strategy to address not just diagnosis of osteoporosis but also prevention and effective treatment.

SPEECH.PARA: In answer to a question asked by Senator Aulich, Senator Bolkus referred to an alleged document that was selectively released yesterday to Mr Peter Hartcher of the Sydney Morning Herald. The first is that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) did not have the courtesy to actually give the document to the Opposition or anyone else—he gave it selectively to Mr Hartcher. PARA.TAB: The claims made in the article were erroneous in the extreme. The Minister claimed that there could be no savings of the kind outlined in the coalition's Fightback package. This is a second attempt by the Government to complain about the figures in the coalition's Fightback package. One of the Treasurers, whose name I have forgotten—I think it was Mr Willis—made some attempt back in December of last year to respond to this aspect of the Fightback package.

The then Treasurer said that it was not sensible to base estimates of net savings on a 1991-92 static base. As everyone knows, the Fightback package was based on 1991-92 figures. That is eminently sensible. The use of Forward Estimates would have caused great concern because they are fairly rubbery and could not be relied upon as being accurate. The 1991-92 figures are, of course, as close as we can get under this Government.

The point was made within this article, again quite incorrectly, that the redundancy payments would be so high in fact as to be above the amount allowed for within the Fightback package. I make it quite clear what that amount was. It was an amount of $200m per year over a three-year period—I think it came to $550m in total. I should point out that the detail with respect to the Fightback package was established well in advance of the estimates that we looked at last year.

The complaint is made that we would have to pay out some thousands of dollars—in fact, a figure of $50,000 per person is used—for redundancy. I am not going to quibble about $50,000, except to say that in Estimates last year the figure used and given to me by the Department was $30,000. Let us not quibble too much about that. In the report to Mr Hartcher—which hopefully I will get at some time—the Minister, the Department or whoever says, `Horror of horrors, we will have to pay this redundancy figure'.

What came out in the Estimates was that just in Asset Services, the provision has been made by the Minister—and this is his answer to me in October last year—that between now and 1993-94 some 850 people will be made redundant. That was the Department's own plan just for Asset Services!

At the end of Question Time, I was given the opportunity to ask Senator Bolkus, `Okay, what provision have you made for the whole Department between now and 1993-94?'. He could not answer the question. This is the man who is supposedly the Government's expert on business enterprises. He is one of the most commercially incompetent and illiterate Ministers in the Government. That is not saying much. That puts him right down in the pits.

The point is that here is a person who should be concerned about what is happening to his Department. Certainly, it is being commercialised. We have no objection to that and we have encouraged the Department to go along that track. We have also encouraged it to go along the track of profit and loss accounts, balance sheets, notes to the accounts and things like that so that we can clearly identify items. In his response, for some reason Minister Bolkus pulled out of the air a figure of $540m. Mr President, I have no idea where the $540m comes from. He says that we made a mistake of $540m. All we offered to do, using the Department's own figures, was make a saving of $230m over a two-year period.

He also referred to Professor Domberger and implied somehow that we used the Domberger model to determine the savings. Nothing could be further from the truth. We looked at each individual business unit. Domberger claims in all the work he has done, as does Rimmer from the Industries Commission, that with a contracting out process there are probably savings that vary between 20 and 35 per cent. If we look simply at the contracting out basis—and it varies on the particular business unit; we cannot generalise—it gives us some idea of the detail and the effort that we put into it. Professor Button would be aware of non-generalisation although he does it fairly frequently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you get on with it? Raise an MPI.
—I think the Minister is going back to the womb.
—If you abuse this process we won't give you leave again.

—The conservative estimate taken was that there would be a 15 per cent saving if work was contracted out rather than done by government. The initial savings, and this was in the prunings of the various areas, are simply based on the facts that came out in last year's Estimates Committee. It was work that we did without having the knowledge of what was going to be in the Forward Estimates or the Budget and we simply used those.

PARA.TAB: Of course, this was pointed out by Mr Willis when he was Treasurer. He said, `We do not like your savings. The reason we do not like your savings is that we were going to do it anyway. So if we were going to do it anyway, you cannot have them'. That was the reason that he said we should not be using the 1991-92 static base. Have you ever heard such nonsense? The Government had been in office for eight years and who was going to believe it? Its credibility was absolutely shot to pieces by this sort of nonsense comment and the report brought out today. The Finance Minister failed, yet here we have Senator Bolkus, who has no credibility when it comes to business matters, thinking he can succeed.

It is not just my belief, it comes from the other side of the Parliament as well. I have also supported the fact that the Department has gone down the commercial track. TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the pharmaceutical industry, to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to move to take note of the statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: I am making this statement today to outline the steps the Government is taking to create an environment in which our pharmaceutical industry will prosper.

The pharmaceutical industry exhibits many of the characteristics which the Government is seeking to encourage in the manufacturing sector. It has the potential to make a major contribution to wealth creation and exports of high value-added manufactures.

It is an industry where competitive advantage is based on innovation and the endeavours of a highly skilled workforce. It offers the opportunity to derive greater economic benefit from our long term investment in our scientific and technological infrastructure.
Pharmaceuticals is also a global industry and there are sound reasons for the Government promoting participation in such industries.
Global industries are dominated by very large firms and the barriers to entry are high:
-our firms need to be very competitive to survive in such an environment;
-they must have access to the latest technology and manufacturing know-how;
-this in turn places competitive pressure on supplier industries with wider benefits for the economy.
The Government is strongly committed to providing an environment in which the industry can realise its full potential.

That commitment to the development of the pharmaceutical industry should be seen in the context of the Government's approach to industry development generally, and high value-added industries in particular.
The major challenge facing Australia today is to address the structural imbalances in our economy and reduce the current account deficit.

Historically, Australia's high standard of living has been very dependent on our role as an exporter of commodities. With the long term downward trend in the real prices of primary commodities, the relative demand for them on world markets and the agricultural protection practised by the major trading blocks there is an urgent need for Australia to diversify its export base.
The consequences of failing to address the structural imbalances in our trading patterns are declining living standards for all Australians and an inability to address our current account problems.

The Government recognises that a strong, dynamic and export oriented manufacturing base is an essential feature of an advanced economy. It also recognises that there is a role for Government in hastening the process of structural change, in upgrading our sources of competitive advantage and creating the mechanisms to link our industries into the global economy.

Government industry policy objectives must therefore be carefully focused on building a profitable and dynamic industrial base and developing our capacity to become a serious participant in high value-added industries.

A central premise of industry policy must be to recognise innovation as the key to sustained economic growth—the Government has a role in supporting firms and industries which take up new technologies, and develop new products and processes.

In establishing policy settings we must recognise that in global industries like pharmaceuticals, companies actively trade location of activity for government bestowed benefits. Given the long lead times, the high risk and the substantial investments involved in the pharmaceutical industry, a stable and attractive policy environment is a pre-requisite for investment.

The rationale for the Government placing a strong emphasis on high value-added manufactures is quite clear. High value-added, or elaborately transformed manufactures, are the fastest growing area of world trade and provide Australia with the opportunity to reduce its dependence on commodities or simply transformed manufactures.

A stronger bias towards high value-added manufactures will mean that the volume and value of our exports will be less susceptible to exchange rate movements and the boom, bust cycles of commodity markets.
More sophisticated or high value-added goods and services are able to command price premiums on world markets which are reflected in higher wages and higher living standards.
Pharmaceuticals is an industry in which Australia has created some competitive advantage
-the foundations for establishing an internationally competitive industry in Australia are already in place.

Our competitive advantage has been created by long term public investment in the education and training of a highly skilled workforce, and our medical research infrastructure and through the provision of first world medical services.

We also have an industry infrastructure which includes a number of medium sized indigenous firms which are already successful exporters and the subsidiaries of the major international pharmaceutical companies with linkages to the world's major markets.

Until recently, Australia has not been perceived as an attractive location for pharmaceutical activity, despite our high quality medical research capability, the availability of highly skilled people and our proximity to the expanding Asian market.

The reasons are obvious—a time-consuming drug approval system and prices for pharmaceutical products which are substantially lower than those of our major trading partners. Health policy objectives clearly had precedence over industry development objectives.
Over the last decade, Australia has reacted to rising pharmaceutical costs by limiting prices.

The introduction of the Factor f scheme has allowed us to retain the substantial benefits of low prices to consumers while capturing the opportunities for wealth creation and extracting an adequate return from substantial public investment in medical research and education and training.
Australia has a low and, until recently with the introduction of the Pharmaceutical Industry Development Program, a declining level of pharmaceutical production.
The import-export ratio in the mid 1980's was 2:1, but now stands at 3:1.

This deterioration is not a reflection of the inability of local firms to be internationally competitive, but is largely the result of disinvestment by multinational pharmaceutical companies as they rationalise their regional production centres to more attractive locations.

This ratio will improve rapidly. The benefits from investments undertaken by companies participating in the scheme will translate into rapidly growing exports. Our export performance is predicted to match and overtake the demand for new and increasingly expensive imported drugs, and increasingly new drugs will be developed and manufactured here.

With the measures already in place and the new initiatives that I will announce today, the Government is confident that it will have in place a framework which will comprehensively address the major impediments to the industry's competitiveness.

In recognition of the negative impact of PBS pricing on industry development, the Government introduced the Factor f scheme in 1987 as a major component of its Pharmaceutical Industry Development Program.
The Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority (PBPA) is charged with taking into account eight factors when determining appropriate prices for products listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

Factor f is so named because it is the sixth factor taken in account by the Pricing Authority. The Authority is required to give due consideration to the level of activity being undertaken by the company in Australia including investment, production and research and development where that activity is internationally competitive.

The scheme has been instrumental in changing industry perceptions about Australia as an investment location. As a result of the outstanding success of the scheme, the Government has decided to extend Factor f until mid-1999:
-in just three years Factor f has generated over $500 million in additional activity;
-companies plan to increase exports of human use pharmaceuticals from $162 million in 1987 to around $540 million a year by 1993;

-470 jobs in the industry have been created; another 390 jobs have been retained in facilities which would otherwise have been shut down. These 860 jobs represent over 10 percent of the industry's workforce;

-the ten participating companies are planning to invest $375 million in new manufacturing and research facilities; as a result of this increased investment activity, over 700 jobs have been created in the construction sector;

-A recent survey of 22 of the major pharmaceutical companies operating in Australia indicates a significant increase in research and development expenditure as a percentage of turnover. R&D has increased from 2.9 per cent of sales in 1987 to over 6.5 per cent in 1990;
-Australia is now firmly established as a strategic centre for manufacture of a number of human use pharmaceuticals.

Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd, the first Factor f participant, has become the Glaxo Group's strategic centre for products manufactured using Blow-Fill-Seal production technology. These products include Glaxo's top selling anti asthma product Ventolin Nebules. Future applications of Blow-Fill-Seal technology will include plastic ampoules and intra nasal dose forms of other new products. Glaxo will invest $114 million in new facilities including $38 million in Blow-Fill-Seal facilities in Australia, effectively doubling its export capacity. Glaxo anticipates it will invest a further $60 million in additional, state-of-the-art production facilities between 1995 and the year 2000. Australia will also become a strategic manufacturing centre for metered dose inhalers using non ozone depleting propellants.

Merck Sharp & Dohme (Australia) Pty Ltd plans to establish a major manufacturing facility in Australia to service world markets. Merck Sharp & Dohme has increased its exports from just $2 million a year in 1986 to $62 million last year and now manufactures a range of products for markets around the world. The company aims to achieve exports of $250 million a year by the end of the decade.

Bristol-Myers Squibb Pharmaceuticals Pty Ltd is investing $11 million in new production facilities at its Noble Park plant in Melbourne including a cardiovascular suite which will employ the latest production technology. This investment has enabled Bristol-Myers Squibb to double its manufacturing capacity to produce a range of products for markets around the world;
-Factor f has also been the catalyst for a number of research based alliances which in the longer term can be expected to result in substantial exports

PARA.TAB: Glaxo Australia and Biota Holdings are supporting research by the CSIRO's Division of Biomolecular Engineering and the Victorian College of Pharmacy into the development of an influenza drug;

Glaxo and Faulding have established a strategic alliance to develop Kapanol, an oral sustained release morphine for the management of severe pain. It will be manufactured by Faulding using raw material produced by Glaxo and will be marketed world wide by the two companies; and

Merck Sharp and Dohme and AMRAD Corporation Ltd, the Australian R&D based company have established an alliance based on an innovative research and comarketing arrangement. Merck Sharp & Dohme has invested over $8 million in AMRAD and a joint venture company, AMRAD Pharmaceuticals Pty Ltd, markets four of Merck Sharp & Dohme's products under licence. This arrangement provides AMRAD with the opportunity to develop marketing expertise and provides a cash flow to fund further R&D. AMRAD is currently the fastest growing pharmaceutical company in Australia and will ultimately have the capability to develop and commercialize a range of Australian biomedical discoveries.

SPEECH.PARA: In extending the scheme, the Government has made a number of changes to ensure it more effectively achieves its objectives:
-the 10 percent cap on individual Factor f entitlements has been removed; and
-some increased flexibility has been introduced in the eligibility criteria, particularly for proposals based on qualitative criteria.

A number of companies which have expressed a strong interest in participating in the scheme will now be able to do so. I am aware of some very exciting proposals from both existing and potential participants which are currently in the pipeline.
The low prices paid for pharmaceutical products in Australia has not been the only constraint on industry development.
Australia has had a relatively slow regulatory system with unique drug evaluation requirements.

In the early 1980's companies were often unwilling to manufacture new products in Australia due to the long delays in products reaching the market. As it is essential for new products to reach the market as soon as possible, Australia has lost opportunities to become a strategic centre for the manufacture of these products for world markets.

As a result of the widespread dissatisfaction with the performance of Australia's drug evaluation system, the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services in March last year asked Professor Peter Baume to conduct an inquiry into our evaluation system and to recommend ways in which the system could be improved.
The Minister has subsequently announced that the recommendations of the Baume review would be implemented in full. Implementation is on schedule.

The Government's prompt acceptance of Professor Baume's recommendations is a demonstration of our commitment to ensuring Australia has a drug evaluation system which is internationally competitive and harmonised with international practice.
The implementation of the Baume recommendations will provide for strict evaluation times which will ensure that new drugs are available in a timely manner.
Our regulatory requirements and procedures will be harmonised with those in the major international markets for pharmaceuticals, particularly the EC and the USA.
And much greater use will be made of the opportunities available for obtaining evaluation reports from other regulatory agencies which also have advanced standards of evaluation.
Progress has already been made in a number of areas including the harmonisation of Australian data requirements and drug evaluation processes with those in the EC and USA is proceeding on target.
I am pleased to note the recent appointment of a new National Manager for the Therapeutic Goods Administration, Dr Geoffrey Vaughan, whose charter is to implement the Baume recommendations.
Protection of intellectual property is a critical issue for research based companies in terms of providing effective patent life to ensure an adequate return on investment.
An important element of the industry development program announced in 1987 was the extension of patent life for pharmaceuticals from 16 to 20 years to compensate for a slow drug registration system.

The Government is concerned that effective patent life in Australia is not reduced by delays in the drug approval process. It is closely monitoring the implementation of improvements to the regulatory system to ensure Australia's patent term remains competitive with that provided by our major trading partners.
Similarly, the Government will monitor and respond to any moves by other countries to extend the patent life for pharmaceuticals.
In 1990 the Government introduced its Minimum Pricing Policy which has, as one of its objectives, the development of a local generic manufacturing industry.
A number of companies have benefited from the Minimum Pricing Policy, including indigenous companies engaged in the production of generics and enhanced generic products.

The pharmaceutical industry in general has welcomed the opportunity for increased price competition and the Australian tax-payer will benefit through the budget savings within the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
The profitability and hence the viability of the local pharmaceutical industry is vitally dependent on the policy environment in which the industry operates.
Primarily for health policy reasons, the pharmaceutical industry is very heavily regulated.

The Government has very clear health policy objectives—it wishes to ensure that pharmaceuticals introduced into the Australian market are safe and effective and that essential drugs are available to the community at an affordable price. It is also concerned to contain budget outlays for health care.

The Government's industry policy objectives are equally clear—it is committed to creating an environment where internationally competitive industries like pharmaceuticals, can maximise their contribution to wealth creation.
Over the 1970's and 1980's, the Government has very successfully contained PBS outlays. Our reaction to rising pharmaceutical costs has been to limit prices.
The costs in terms of industry development have been high, with the closure of manufacturing facilities and a growing pharmaceutical trade deficit.

While providing a more favourable investment environment for the pharmaceutical industry has implications for budget outlays, the Government is firmly of the view that we must strike a more appropriate balance between the need to ensure high quality health outcomes at the best possible cost and industry development.
Our ability to maintain a high standard of living and to continue to provide first world medical services to the community are at stake.

The Government recognises that the industry continues to receive diverse policy signals which may impact on investment decisions and the industry's perceptions of the Government's commitment to industry development.
The extension of Factor f and the implementation of the Baume recommendations are important steps in the right direction.

To promote a greater understanding of the environment in which the industry operates, to generate a high level of commitment to industry development and to ensure the industry better understands the need to balance a range of competing policy objectives, the Government has decided to establish an industry/government consultative forum.
This decision is very much in line with the recommendations made recently by the industry to the Prime Minister's Science Council.

The forum will comprise a senior official from both the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and three industry representatives:
-Mr Paul Bell, Managing Director, Merck, Sharp and Dohme (Australia) Pty Ltd
-Dr Ed Tweddell, Executive Director, Pharmaceutical Group, FH Faulding and Co. Ltd
-Mr Ken Windle, Managing Director, Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd.
Additional members will be invited to participate in the forum when issues requiring their specific expertise arise.

The forum will provide a valuable mechanism for the provision of advice to Government on a wide range of issues affecting the industry and the development of more effective linkages between industry and the research sector.
However, there are a number of issues which I, in consultation with the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, have requested the Forum's early advice:
-the authority to prescribe for products priced $30 or more which limits prescribing of more expensive drugs;
-the Minimum Pricing Policy; and
-possible changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority guidelines to allow the Authority to take into account the wider industry development ramifications when setting prices.
In providing advice on these issues, the forum will be required to take into account both the Government's health and industry policy objectives.
The Forum will report direct to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services and myself on these particular issues within a specified time frame.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A Vision for the Pharmaceutical Industry

SPEECH.PARA: The initiatives I have announced today, are a reflection of the Government's commitment to providing the pharmaceutical industry with an environment where innovation is rewarded and encouraged. A dynamic and export oriented pharmaceutical industry will have benefits for all Australians.
It is a recognition of the need to provide the industry with a more predictable and stable environment.
Our long term goal is to build a research based pharmaceutical industry which has the depth and capability to commercialise locally developed products for world markets.

The Government has a vision for the industry which will see Australia firmly established as a strategic location in the Asian region for R&D and manufacturing activity by the world's major pharmaceutical companies.
It will be an industry with a number of strong indigenous firms with linkages into international markets.

The Government has created an environment where the development of partnerships between indigenous firms, multinational pharmaceutical companies and our world class research base will ensure we are better able to appropriate the gains from local innovation.
A rapidly growing and dynamic industry will provide employment opportunities for our scientists and other highly skilled Australians.
A strong focus on innovation and the adoption of state-of-the-art production technology and international best practice will ensure the industry sustains its competitive position.

The industry's response to the more recent improvements to its operating environment have been extremely encouraging—a positive trade balance in pharmaceuticals and exports of $2 billion by the year 2000 is now not out of the question.
I have no doubt that the industry will rise to the challenge in terms of the ambitious targets it has set itself for the end of the decade.
