PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pharmaceutical industry in Australia has had a long history of inquiries trying to solve the problem created for industry development by Australia's national pharmaceutical benefits scheme. There was one in 1977; two in 1979; three in 1980; one in 1981; two in 1985; two in 1986; three in 1987; one in 1988; and two in 1989. That shows how many inquiries there have been into the supply of pharmaceuticals. This is another step in trying to sort out the industry and some of the problems it faces.

PARA.TAB: It has been a case of trying to serve two apparently mutually exclusive objectives: inexpensive access to human use pharmaceuticals, and local industry development. The Factor f scheme has been and is an attempt to reconcile both. Last year the Bureau of Industry Economics evaluated the Factor f scheme after its first few years of operation. A report followed another report in the mid-1980s by the Industries Assistance Commission, which was on the whole less enthusiastic about assistance, or at least neutralisation of the distortions, than perhaps the Government or the coalition would have liked.

Today, partly in response to this latest BIE report, the Government has announced continuation of the Factor f program until 1999. As the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) outlined in detail in the speech he has incorporated, in recent years some very promising developments have occurred in the industry, often through joint ventures between industry participants and Australia's highly regarded medical research bodies.

Overall, we have been told that there has been an increase in activity since the inception of the scheme of over $500m, with planned exports increasing from $162m to $540m in 1993. Research and development activity has increased to over 6.5 per cent of turnover from 2.9 per cent. On these measures at least the scheme so far has appeared to have led to a stronger local pharmaceutical industry.

The Factor f scheme has been operating since 1987. The coalition has not opposed it in the broad in recognition of the clear and unique market distortion which exists as a result of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority is a monopoly buyer on behalf of all Australians. Not surprisingly, and as economic theory would suggest, it has the power, which it has used, to keep the prices as low as possible. This has resulted in sizeable gains to Australians who have been able to buy drugs at very low prices—among the lowest in the world. The Report of the Bureau of Industry Economics quotes from the report of the Industries Assistance Commission in 1986, which concluded that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the international price comparisons leave little doubt that, in aggregate, PBS pricing policies have reduced prices for PBS drugs below the levels which would prevail in the absence of the scheme.

PARA.TAB: The other side of the coin, however, is that local companies have had no incentive to establish their own research and development operations, which is absolutely vital to growth in this research driven industry. Pharmaceutical companies need to get a return which is great enough to finance research and development of new products. It is this element that they just had not been getting through the PBPB, as it then was; it was a missing factor.

There have been different views put over the years about what should be done. There have been numerous inquiries under governments of various persuasions keen to see a local industry developed. As already mentioned, the Industries Assistance Commission in the mid-1980s essentially concluded that arrangements should be left as they were because the impact on the local industry, although negative, had been small. I quote from the Bureau of Industry Economics report:

SPEECH.PARA: Conceivably the most important way in which the pricing environment might have adversely affected the level of activity during this period is in terms of potential opportunities forgone.
In other words, forget about local industry development and continue to buy the drugs which Australians need at the lowest possible prices. Certainly that is a large gain that we cannot ignore.

PARA.TAB: However, it does not seem reasonable or sensible to impair growth of one industry because of potentially dynamic government-sponsored arrangements, if that distortion can be overcome in a way which eventually generates an overall net gain to the community. There is a good case to at least neutralise the distortion as far as local industries are concerned. In other words, not to give them excessive assistance, but to give them a neutral springboard, just as other industries should not have to put up with costly regulations and requirements and so on.

This is, in essence, the reasoning behind the factor F program, which adds another price factor—the sixth factor—to the list to be taken into account when the Authority buys pharmaceuticals. As I have already said, this scheme has been operating now for nearly five years and was due to lapse in 1993, pending the review by the Bureau of Industry Economics.

Late last year, the Bureau released its analysis and evaluation of the program. One would have to say that the Bureau was not over-enthusiastic about the scheme. It did not explicitly recommend its continuation, but it did say that continuation of the scheme would probably be necessary to ensure continued growth in the industry. Its report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: failure to continue to compensate for suppressed prices may mean that Australia misses out on the current window of opportunity as a regional base for new activity.

It also recommended a number of improvements, if the scheme were to continue, which would help to ensure national benefits, and principal amongst these was that the rate of compensation should be reduced. Specifically, its recommendations were: payment of compensation through explicit pricing increases rather than notional amounts; reduction of the ceiling on price increases from the world to the EC average; removal of the 10 per cent price cap on annual price increases; more equitable treatment of domestic value added for existing products; inclusion of hospital sales of ethical pharmaceuticals, and more sympathetic consideration of eligibility on the basis of qualitative factors.

PARA.TAB: The Bureau also recommended that, if the scheme were to be continued, it should be subject to an evaluation not later than five years hence. Overall, one could say that the Bureau was equivocal about the impact of the scheme, although it unequivocally said that up to now it thought that the costs outweighed the benefits, that national welfare had been reduced. But it is also fair to say that the Bureau concluded on balance that the risk of not continuing with the scheme—the cost opportunities lost—could be greater than the loss generated by the scheme. In other words, we could not afford to miss out on that window of opportunity.

The coalition broadly agrees with the BIE's evaluation, although we also think that there are other impediments to the industry's development which must be addressed, and I will come to these a little later. We recognise that there is a distortion in the market created, not only by the pricing arrangements, but also by the lengthy—and I repeat that, lengthy—drug evaluation and approval procedures which the Minister has alluded to in his statement.

However, we accept the BIE's caution that the industry should not be overcompensated for the price distortions and nor should the scheme be so directive and bureaucratic that inefficient patterns of production result. That would be counterproductive for the industry and for the community.

Today, the Government, as I have already said, has announced the continuation of the scheme until 1999. It has also picked up a couple of the Bureau's recommendations—namely, removal of the 10 per cent price cap on annual price increases, and some increased flexibility in the eligibility criteria.

According to the BIE report, the removal of the capping will allow firms to obtain the full entitlement that their commitment to additional activity would otherwise allow. Previous arrangements did not provide for full entitlement in all circumstances. The BIE notes that this will go some way in addressing the issue of undercompensation for some firms.

The BIE noted that the qualitative and quantitative hurdles sometimes prevented firms from getting access to the scheme when, in a deregulated environment, the level of activity would have been increased. The increased flexibility in the eligibility criteria has been accepted to address this problem, which is primarily one of under-compensation.

The Minister's statement appears silent regarding the basis for factor F pricing. Will the world average price, rather than the EC average price, continue to be used contrary to the Bureau's strong recommendation? Will compensation be paid through explicit price increases as the BIE recommends? The community's interest would be better served if the Government explained if and why it has rejected some of the BIE's recommendations.

In summary, the coalition recognises the particular problems of this industry and has said so on many occasions to the pharmaceutical manufacturers. We want to see a truly competitive, locally based industry develop. There is a window of opportunity which we should, by all accounts, have the ability and the capacity to take full advantage of. We have some of the best medical research laboratories in the world. We have very talented people. It would be tragic if that potential were undermined by arrangements in the health industry, even if these were for the best of reasons—the health of the Australian community.

Certainly there has been an urgent need to improve drug approval procedures. It is encouraging to see that in the statement the Minister recognised the importance of this to the industry. When I read that the Minister said that Australia has had a relatively slow regulatory system with unique evaluation requirements, I was amazed. What an understatement. Examples of some of the delays in approvals of drugs that have been overseas are numerous. Senator Knowles has outlined on innumerable occasions the delay in the approval of oestrogen patches. There has also been delay in the approval of Marvelon, Clozapine, Alfentanyl, and a number of other drugs. When Professor Baume completed his report into drug evaluation in Australia, the coalition welcomed it and called on the Government to implement the recommendations immediately.

Already a number of Professor Baume's recommendations have been implemented but, as yet, it is too soon to be able to judge the effectiveness of these reforms. However, there are still examples constantly coming to our attention of delays in drug approvals. One example is a drug called GCSF, or growth colony stimulating factor. GCSF was first discovered in Australia and is now available in at least 17 countries around the world, including the USA, UK, Germany and New Zealand, but it has still not been given general marketing approval here. It is actually mentioned in the BIE report as an example of a rare Australian pharmaceutical discovery. This Government seems to have a long way to go in fixing the problem of delays in the approval of drugs like this.

There is also a problem with a drug called Benemid, manufactured by Merck Sharp and Dohme. Due to manufacturing problems, the Australian formulation was taken off the market. The company sought approval from the TGA to place the New Zealand formulation of Benemid on the market. The New Zealand product met all specifications. However, approval was not given. The irony is that, in order to gain access to the product, some doctors have been advised by TGA that their patients can gain supplies from the New Zealand market. So Australians have access to this drug, but through New Zealand.

There has been an urgent need to improve drug approval procedures and, as I have said before, it is encouraging to hear the Minister recognise the importance of this to the industry. We also recognise the importance of the factor F program and the changes the Government has introduced which should improve the industry's efficiency.

One of the other areas of concern in the pharmaceutical industry is drug approvals for `export only' products. This matter was addressed specifically in a Bureau of Industry Economics report, which noted:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the new 1989 Therapeutic Goods legislation, the listing of export-only products on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods is to involve the same review process as applies to the listing of goods to be supplied to the Australian market (ie. largely on the basis of Section 26(1) of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989). That is, export-only products will have to meet all Australian requirements unless specific assurance is obtained from the importing country that it is prepared to accept goods that do not meet those requirements.

It must be questioned as to why there is a need to impose Australian requirements on goods produced specifically for another country, without request by the importing country for such scrutiny. Such requirements would seem unnecessary because there is already a mechanism in place that is internationally recognised for providing information to importing countries if so required. . . Under this scheme, administered by the TGA, an importing country can request information from the regulatory authority in the exporting country in regard to whether the product is sold in the country of origin, whether it meets GMP standards and whether the product conforms to that stated. . .
The pharmaceutical industry does not object to controls over export-only drugs, but to excessive controls over these products.
This is not a document from the pharmaceutical industry; this is what is said in a report of the Bureau of Industry Economics. The report goes on to say:

In view of the importance of efficient procedures in this area for export activity, the Bureau considers that regulation in the area of export-only drugs should be directed solely at achieving as efficiently as possible, industry and trade policy objectives.

There is no reference to this in this statement. We are told in the current statement that the Minister has placed before us today that one aspect of the problem is being looked at. But this issue is not being looked at.

PARA.TAB: A company which is located just around the corner from my office is an example of what is happening. The new export certification requirements mean that that company must include on its certificates the words that the product is for export only. That is Australia's requirement. But what is happening? The company is finding that its export markets are closing because, by implication, the importing countries think that drugs manufactured only for export must be of a somewhat lesser quality. Importing countries are of a mind that we are dumping on to them a drug or a therapeutic good which does not meet good manufacturing standards or practice. In fact, I have explained and the Bureau has explained that that is not the case, that international standards have to be met.

We are in fact hindering the export of products because of a regulation that is not required by importing countries and that is not required by international standards. It is a case of over-regulation. So what has happened to that company around the corner from me in Clayton? Thousands of people are about to lose their jobs in Nissan and hundreds of people will lose their jobs in other industries associated with the car industry. Reports come into my office daily of other companies in the area closing down. When we need jobs, what is happening? The American parent company of that pharmaceutical company around the corner from me wants to invest $25m in capital plant in the area. But it is not doing so because of the uncertainty and because of the reduction in export markets created by this sort of policy. Jobs are going down the drain.

And where is that parent company thinking of putting that plant? Not in Australia, but somewhere in Asia. This is not happening because of lack of support or money. I have spoken about this sort of thing before in this chamber. The parent company wants the regulations to be freed up. It is not trying to do anything tricky. All it wants to do is abide by international standards and good manufacturing practice and to be free from the burden and the bondage of over-regulation. Yet Australians are expecting that company to write on its export certification the words `For export only'. As I said, this regulation is not required by the importing country and it is not required by international standards. This regulation which we have imposed on ourselves is actually hindering the pharmaceutical export market. So, unless these other problems are addressed, the report that the Minister has tabled is cold comfort.

The Australian company that I have referred to has a dozen other products up for re-registration in a major overseas market. However, the export certificates are not acceptable to the country to which it exports and it is losing dollars. So dollars already are being lost; jobs are being lost because the parent company is not investing capital; and also we look like losing yet another market. I would not be surprised if that Australian company were to come around to tell me that it is reducing its manufacturing in the area as well and that maybe more jobs will be lost. That company has already put off 21 people in the last 12 months or so.

The Minister's statement is short on details regarding its response to the BIE recommendations and, indeed, the expected cost to taxpayers of the new arrangements. As I have already said, the coalition does not believe that lack of information about the scheme serves either the interests of the industry or the community well. We certainly would like more information on all these matters before embracing all elements of the new arrangements. In addition, we consider that there is a need for ongoing assessment of the program to ensure that the benefits are there not only for the industry but for all Australians.

The fact is, however, that the Government's announcement today, welcomed as it might be by the industry, does not go far enough. It addresses but one element of the industry's disadvantages. I have addressed the other ones—the delay in approvals and the problems with the `export only' certification. The coalition is committed to reducing the industry's costs across the board and improving the environment in which it operates.

One of the other problems that the industry has outlined to me concerns transport. Some of the products that the industry manufactures are very susceptible to heat, have a use-by date and can be damaged. I was given the example of export-bound pharmaceutical products which were totally damaged by water after sitting on a tarmac, a wharf or something for some time. Drugs waiting to be exported cannot sit on wharves. There needs to be an assurance that these exports will be dealt with efficiently on the waterfront. The goods have to be delivered on time and not left sitting on wharves for long periods in the heat and rain. So there needs to be an environment which is reliable, especially in the waterfront area.

As well as creating an environment which reduces industry's costs in terms of transport, the coalition will be bringing about the abolition of payroll tax and wholesale sales tax. It will make significant micro-economic reforms, which will be just as significant for the pharmaceutical industry as any other industry. However, in particular they will be significant for industries that export. Indeed, from discussions between the industry and the shadow Minister we know that the gains to the industry from our policies will be significant indeed.

The problem with this Government is that it has concentrated on the specific rather than the broad. There is no doubt that the pharmaceutical industry had very major and specific impediments. This should not divert attention from the equally urgent need to tackle economy-wide impediments so that the industry can build on its strength and become truly world competitive. I know that when the coalition puts its policies into place, the industry will benefit greatly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome the statement on the pharmaceutical industry released by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. This is a very important statement, released at a time when we are seeking to enhance Australia's economic self-reliance and increase the value and volume of our exports. The pharmaceutical industry represents the very kind of high technology manufacturing that we need to encourage in this country. This industry has massive growth potential and in time could help significantly in our trade performance and balance of payments.

PARA.TAB: In addition, the industry has the potential to tap into the clever country by building on the important and internationally recognised expertise here in Australia covering a wide variety of medical and paramedical services and industries. Our medical schools are excellent and as a result Australia is a world leader in biomedical research. Our own doctors and surgeons are at the forefront of breakthroughs in treatment and the understanding of human physiology, and we have diagnostic services which are on a par with anything in the world.

The Australian Democrats believe that with careful strategic planning we can develop an integrated medical industry in this country spanning research, treatment and support services which not only delivers economic and health benefits to the Australian public, but also to the international community. Australia could conceivably become an international centre of medical excellence across a range of fields.

The statement before us today is an important step in developing Australia's role in pharmaceuticals manufacturing. We welcome the extension of the Factor f scheme until mid-1999. As the Minister has outlined, pharmaceuticals research and development has doubled from 2.9 per cent of sales in 1987 to over 6.5 per cent in 1990; a statistic that can be directly attributed to changes introduced in 1987 under the pharmaceutical industry development program.

We support the Government's commitment to fostering Australian research and development in all areas, and not only that of the pharmaceutical industry. However, we strongly criticise the Government's recent reduction of research and development write-offs from 150 per cent to 125 per cent. The Australian Democrats believe that this write-off should be returned immediately to 150 per cent if the Government is to have any credibility about its commitment to R&D investment. The Minister mentions a significant increase in R&D expenditure in 22 major pharmaceutical firms, and I have already outlined those statistics. I would be interested to see the percentages this year after the reduction to 125 per cent. Despite these figures, it should be noted that, as reported in yesterday's Age:

SPEECH.PARA: Local subsidiaries of multinational companies dominate the Australian pharmaceutical industry, supplying 94 per cent of the market.

We are not talking about Australian-owned companies with long-term profits staying in Australia. A locally grown pharmaceutical industry owned by Australians would be desirable, and we must take steps to encourage local competition in selected areas to balance the current dominance of multinationals. A return to the 150 per cent R&D write-off would facilitate this process.

PARA.TAB: In addition, reform of the drug evaluation procedures are to be supported, bringing Australia into line with practices overseas. The Australian Democrats support immediate implementation of the Baume recommendations as outlined in the statement, along with continued monitoring of the effective patent life of a new drug.

Reform of the drug evaluation process is long overdue, not only from an industry perspective, but also from the point of view of the very many terminally and seriously ill patients who have suffered from the slow, overly bureaucratic and unsympathetic regulation regime. While it is pleasing to at last see some progress in this area, I would remind Senator Button that the Government dragged its feet for years on this issue before finally deciding to do something.

The recommendations made by Professor Baume in his review were far from radical, but he did identify one of the major issues in the administration of therapeutic goods, that is, the question of timely availability of drugs. The desirability of balancing that concern against the need to maintain high standards of safety is now going to have to be a major consideration. Our drug regulation system has in many ways been defined by two medical disasters: thalidomide and AIDS. These two catastrophes represent the opposite ends of the regulations spectrum. On the one hand, we want a system that provides adequate protection from dangerous or potentially dangerous new drugs, and on the other hand we want to make sure that we give people who have a terminal or life-threatening illness the best possible chance of survival.

Professor Baume considered this tension between safety and availability very carefully and he pointed to the need for a balance between these two concerns. He also highlighted the fact that this balance was not really covered anywhere in the existing legislation and he saw that omission as having a significant impact on the performance of the Therapeutic Goods Administration and the perception it had of itself.

Professor Baume also observed publicly—following the release of his report—that the TGA had virtually made up its own policies, because it was effectively operating in a policy vacuum. He noted that the drug evaluation branch within the TGA had never committed itself seriously to timeliness and seemed not to have in place any mechanisms to allow it to achieve prompt evaluation for most drugs. In short, there was a lack of accountability in the evaluation process generally and Professor Baume's report recommended some very specific time lines and performance indicators.

Late last year the Senate passed legislation rectifying the imbalance in the Therapeutic Goods Act, giving our drug evaluators a clear statutory direction that timeliness is now to be one of their main aims. That legislation also provided much of the framework for reform of the TGA. The Democrats were strong supporters of this legislation, as we have been of the Baume review generally.

The pace of reform still drags in some areas of our drug evaluation process, especially in the area of early access by terminally ill people to drugs which may be unapproved or experimental. However, overall, Professor Baume has done much to further the cause of sensible reform in this area and the Australian Democrats were—and remain—fully supportive of the Government's decision to implement these recommendations in full.

We also support the establishment of an industry/government consultative forum, comprising DITAC officials and industry representatives, as a means of facilitating communication and understanding between industry and government on what may sometimes be competing policy and social objectives. In our opinion, such a forum should also include representatives of the medical profession and consumer groups, so that a wider range of issues than those simply related to the operations of pharmaceutical companies in Australia can be canvassed more widely.

I refer to a report in yesterday's Age which I think is very pertinent to this issue. It indicated that some $200m a year is spent by the pharmaceutical industry on promoting their products to doctors. However, industry sources have suggested that the figure is closer to $100m, but this still represents an enormous sum of money; possibly as much as $8,000 to $10,000 per doctor, as suggested by Doctor Ken Harvey, a Melbourne microbiologist. Indeed, in a submission to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs the AMA has compared this enormous sum with the `mere hundreds of thousands of dollars put into independent education' about prescribed drug use and abuse.

The Australian Democrats believe that there should be more information on the public record about the vast sums of money spent by pharmaceutical companies on drug promotion to doctors in Australia, what this promotion involves and the kinds of freebies doctors are given.

I note that recently the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) stated that every year some 20,000 to 40,000 people end up in hospital as a result of incorrect use of medications. We believe that both the medical profession and the pharmaceutical industry must bear some of the responsibility for education and a change in community attitudes regarding drug use and abuse. We hope that this very important public health issue will be dealt with by this new consultative forum at the earliest opportunity.

In addition, it is our hope that this forum will recognise the public interest of any possible changes to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority guidelines when it examines the issue of drug pricing later this year. This is an issue of access to health services for disadvantaged groups, not simply one of profits for drug companies. Vital drugs must be affordable and accessible to all through the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

With those provisos, we welcome the statement and hope that it goes some way towards developing an integrated medical services industry in this country which will help Australia become more economically self-reliant and which will deliver significant health benefits to Australians and the rest of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to amplify several remarks which have been made by Senator Sowada and Senator Patterson relating to the statement made by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on the pharmaceutical industry. I want to pick up two points: firstly, the point just made by Senator Sowada in relation to the close and potentially very dangerous links between the commercial development of drugs and their very heavy promotion by drug companies; and, secondly, the point which was touched on by Senator Patterson, namely, the failure of Australia to adequately develop some of the very good research work which is carried out in this country.

PARA.TAB: I pick up the second point first, and give two examples. Senator Patterson referred to the work which has gone on in Melbourne over 25 years on a number of cell stimulating factors which have now resulted in the commercialisation of that work overseas. The point that Senator Patterson was making was that while the drugs resulting from that work are now available overseas, they are not available in Australia. The point I want to make is that the commercialisation of that research work, which was carried out at enormous public expense over 25 years, should have gone on in this country and should not have gone on overseas.

The second example to which I draw attention is the work which went on over some years at the James Cook University on the extraction of a very effective UV blocking substance which could be incorporated into cream and used as a skin protectant against ultraviolet light. This is a very important development because Queensland has the highest incidence of skin cancer in the world and Australians, generally, have a very high incidence. This was a natural substance which had considerable benefits in terms of protecting humans against what will almost certainly be a much greater incidence of ultraviolet light. Yet again, that development—that fundamental research work, which went on over quite some years—has passed out of Australia's hands and, I understand, is now in the hands of ICI and is likely to be developed overseas.

In this general area there is no doubt that in the past Australia has been, as several speakers have said, a leader in medical research, both in the universities and in a number of research institutes around the country. We are in danger of losing that pre-eminent position because of the downgrading of education in general, and research effort in the universities in particular, in recent years under the Hawke and now the Keating Government. That needs to be substantially reversed if we are going to keep that pre-eminent position. Beyond that—and not only in the medical area, but certainly in the medical area—we have failed to turn that often excellent research work into products which can then be marketed and which would be of longer term economic benefit to this country. That is the basis of Senator Button's statement.

I simply stress that we need to perform much better in that area. I do not see a great deal in Senator Button's statement that will necessarily guarantee that, although I agree with Senator Sowada that we support this statement. It is good as far as it goes, but perhaps we need to go much further. Much more emphasis needs to be placed on the Australian pharmaceutical industry rather than simply multinational companies which are operating in this country.

Turning to the other point, there is no doubt that in recent decades we have seen massive corruption in the pharmaceutical industry when it comes to those very large vested interests and their ability to promote the use of drugs which are worth hundreds of millions of dollars to them in sales. We have seen the results of tests which have not been based on properly carried out research work, and which should have been submitted to the regulatory authorities, being manufactured. We have seen the suppression of information by companies which should have made that information available to the regulatory authorities. It is absolutely necessary that the regulatory authorities in this country, no less than in other countries, have available to them independent sources of information; they should not be totally dependent upon the information provided by the company which is seeking to register the particular drug for human use.

In that respect—this is the last point I want to pick up—I was disturbed to received a reply from Senator Button a few weeks ago to a question of mine relating to the close links between commercial interests and research work. The question was actually based not in the medical area but in another area. In the course of his reply, Senator Button pointed out that research workers in this country are now spending 20 per cent of their time writing grant applications and making reports back to the grantees of research funds. I find it somewhat disturbing that people who are very often at the forefront of research work have to spend one-fifth of their time involved in that sort of activity.

Senator Button went on to point out that in his view this was an advantage because not only did it link the research work with the commercial company but also—I do not have his words in front of me, so I will paraphrase them—it helps to set the agenda of the research work. I find that rather frightening if one carries it over into the context of medical research. Medical research—which should be unfettered by commercial interests—should be designed, without reservation, for furthering human benefit in terms of human health, and should not be linked in any way with these extremely powerful commercial interests which might be able to distort the results of that work. For instance, one would see a movement to those drugs which are likely to be more profitable rather than those drugs which are likely to be of greater benefit. The closer ties between the commercial interests and the university and research institute activities, which we have seen under this Labor Government and which have been specifically encouraged by this Labor Government, are an extremely dangerous development.

It may seem that the two points that I have made are paradoxically inconsistent. I want to emphasise that the fundamental research work should be divorced from those commercial interests. When research developments indicate that a commercial possibility can develop from that research work, it seems to me that the Government has not sufficiently created the conditions so that either government or private interests can take up that research work and ensure that those developments and their commercially profitable drugs, or whatever other agents come out the other end, are kept within this country. I stress those two points to the Minister in response to this statement on the pharmaceutical industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports of the Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: No. 2—Construction of a new permanent repository for Australian Archives at East Burwood, Victoria.
No. 3—Installation of fire sprinklers to the International Terminal Building at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: PUBLIC WORKS COMMITTEE
31 March 1992
Mr President
The first report I have just tabled relates to the proposed redevelopment by the CSIRO of its facilities at North Ryde, New South Wales. The main elements of the proposal are:

PARA.TAB: a rationalisation and consolidation of the CSIRO accommodation at North Ryde
a progressive release of approximately 15.8 hectares of identified surplus land and up to 11 development lots to create a science and technology park
the retention of principal CSIRO buildings in good condition
the provision for all of CSIRO's anticipated accommodation needs for the foreseeable future in existing buildings—upgraded as necessary and state-of-the-art new buildings

SPEECH.PARA: The estimated out-turn cost of the work is $98 million to be funded from the sale and or lease of surplus land at North Ryde.

The Committee found that the standard of facilities at North Ryde restricts the continuing development of industrially significant research initiatives with a high national priority for the biotechnology, mining and minerals, energy exploration and food industries as well as work of major environmental significance.
Each of the divisions at North Ryde plays a major role in providing research vital to its industry sector. These sectors represent major components of the Australian economy and include:

TAB.TAB: coal with exports of $6 billion
minerals with exports of $16 billion
manufactured foods with exports of $17 billion

PARA.TAB: pharmaceutical and diagnostic products currently imported at a cost of $3 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: In recommending that the proposal proceed the Committee has concluded that the development of a prestige science and technology park by the CSIRO at North Ryde is the most cost effective method available to it of providing the funds necessary for the development of high quality research facilities.

As the proposal has been referred at a very advanced conceptual stage the Committee has recommended that CSIRO provide it with detailed plans of each aspect of the proposal prior to the commencement of construction.

The Committee is also satisfied, following assurances from CSIRO, that adequate provision has been made for additional expansion of facilities at North Ryde should this be necessary in the future and that the redevelopment strategy developed by CSIRO is realistic in current market conditions.

Mr President, there is one aspect of the proposal which the Committee believes should not remain at North Ryde but should be relocated to the Riverina Region of New South Wales—I am referring to the Food Research Laboratory of the Division of Food Processing.

The Committee believes that the Food Research Laboratory can operate effectively from the Riverina Region as it has good transport links and an existing scientific base on which CSIRO could build. At the same time it would provide a stimulus to the scientific and industrial sectors in an important food growing and processing area.

The Committee strongly disagrees with the working party set up to examine the future structure of the Division of Food Processing which rejected non-capital locations with the professional needs of scientists being an overriding criteria.

The Committee believes that CSIRO should be taking a national view when it examines such issues. In this situation it has a perfect opportunity to assist regional development, allow closer interaction with both food producers and processors and provide opportunities for contact with other scientists working in these industries.

Having considered the evidence presented by CSIRO and from the Riverina Region and taking into account the views of the Sectional Committee which visited the area, the Committee has recommended that the Food Research Laboratory be transferred to the Riverina Region and that the Minister for Science and Technology do all within his power to ensure that the transfer takes place.

The Committee has not recommended a particular site although the Sectional Committee did inspect a number of sites adjacent to the Charles Sturt University at Wagga Wagga. The Committee believes that the question of a particular site should be a matter for discussion between the CSIRO and the relevant authorities in the Riverina Region.
The second report which I have tabled deals with the proposed construction of a new permanent repository for the Australian Archives at East Burwood, Victoria.
This new building will provide up-to-date, climate controlled storage facilities for permanent value Commonwealth records in the custody of Archives in Victoria.
The estimated cost of the proposed work is 6.5 million dollars at October 1991 prices.
The Committee has recommended the construction of the proposed repository.

At present, permanent value Commonwealth records are stored in a former dry cleaning factory in the suburb of Brighton. The Committee concluded, after inspecting the Brighton repository, that if permanent value Commonwealth records remain stored there, many irreplaceable records will be lost. In fact some have already been lost and others severely damaged. There is therefore an urgent need for Archives to be provided with a modern facility in which to store permanent value records in Victoria. Constructing a new repository at the existing site was considered impractical.

After an exhaustive site selection process for a new site, Archives settled on a site at East Burwood for the new repository. The site is eminently suited, being in a designated technology park, and not excessively distant from the Melbourne central business district.
A larger site could have been purchased but more distant from the main users of Archival materials.

The building itself will provide office accommodation, an area for conservation and a large storage area. The storage area will be on three levels. It will have a curved roof to accelerate water run-off, an essential requirement for buildings of this type.
The design is somewhat austere, but nevertheless reflects a need for functionality and a need for the building to be constructed of materials reflecting some cost-consciousness.

The Committee questioned Archives about the ability of the building to be expanded. Archives advised the Committee that once all permanent value records are transferred to the new building, the building will have adequate capacity for another ten to twelve years growth. If by then there is a need to expand further, the site is large enough for extensions to the building to be provided. These extensions would provide additional storage area for another ten to twelve years.
The building will be provided with a number of special features, including strengthened floors, special air-conditioning and fire protection measures. The need for these features was justified.

One thing I would like to mention in conclusion is that the Committee questioned Archives about their involvement in the Centenary of Federation. As Senators will know, Archives is the custodian of an extensive collection of papers relating to Federation.

Archives advised the Committee that it will be looking to increasing publicity about its activities and holdings of material relating to Federation in its custody. I'm sure honourable Members will join me in supporting this nationally important endeavour.
The third report I have tabled relates to the installation of fire sprinklers to the International Terminal Building (ITB) at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

I should say at the outset that during its investigation the Committee took the view that this project should be examined on its merits and in isolation from issues relating to the third runway at Sydney Airport. Construction of the third runway was exempted from the scrutiny of the Committee on the grounds of urgency by the House of Representatives on 14 November 1991.

The ITB was opened in 1970 and met all the then relevant codes. Airport terminal buildings are not expressly covered by codes but they need to have adequate protection. A number of fire hazard reports have recommended installation of fire sprinklers to provide safety for the occupants of the building and to protect the property. Other improvements to provide smoke isolation, emergency evacuation system and additional fire exits were recommended.
Since the Federal Airports Authority (FAC) assumed responsibility for Sydney Airport on 1 January 1988 :

PARA.TAB: additional fire exits were constructed as part of a project which entailed a number of improvements to the ITB and was completed in 1989
smoke isolation measures have been substantially completed on existing stairwells and escalators

SPEECH.PARA: The FAC has installed fire sprinklers in the International Terminal Complex at Sydney Airport which is scheduled for commissioning in December 1992.

The design of this building was based on the assumption that the ITB would be upgraded by the provision of a sprinkler system so that a fire originating in the ITB would be contained within that building. The provision of a fire sprinkler system has been evaluated by the FAC as being necessary for the protection of both the occupants and the building and to achieve Building Code of Australia compliance. The building is vast and fire fighting after detection has been evaluated as being very difficult.
While the Committee has recommended that the work proceed there are a number of issues in the report on which I should comment.

The continued absence of a master plan for Sydney Airport is a matter of serious concern. In fact in 1988 in reporting on the construction of the International Terminal Complex the Committee recommended that the FAC prepare a master plan as expeditiously as possible to ensure the overall orderly development and operation of the Airport.

While the FAC has appointed a consultant to finalise the master plan the Committee has recommended that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation direct the FAC to complete the master plan as a matter of extreme urgency.

I should add that in the absence of a master plan the Committee is loath to recommend further work at Sydney Airport. However as this project concerns an issue of public safety the Committee has no option but to agree to the work proceeding.

The Committee is concerned at the cost of the project—$14.6 million—and has recommended that the FAC review all aspects of the proposal to determine areas of possible cost savings. In relation to cost the Committee has also recommended that FAC commission a fire safety study to determine whether savings can be made in the provision of fire sprinklers. Evidence was given to the Committee which indicated that savings may be possible by limiting sprinklers to areas where they are required for life safety reasons or as cost effective fire protection.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
