TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I am sure you will not remember what I was talking about four weeks ago when this debate was adjourned, but I was making various points on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.4) 1991. I was about to move to the provisions relating to changes in the law about tax deductibility for the restoration of mine sites.

PARA.TAB: Under the system that existed before the advent of these amendments, the Act was very ambiguous. It seemed to be very inconsistent about whether restoration of the mine had to be carried out in one piece—in other words, one total operation—to be eligible for tax deductibility or whether it could be done over a certain amount of time. Since this measure was introduced to encourage restoration of the environment, there have already been two or three amendments.

The Act allowed deduction for the restoration of mine sites, but because of bad drafting the provisions were very ambiguous. On my reading of the legislation, it seemed to me that the mine site had to be restored all in one go. In mining practice that is impossible because restoration of the site actually starts the day mining is started. When an open-cut mine is created, the first practice is to take the topsoil away from the area and stockpile it. That is the first act of restoration. The dumps are created to store the mullock, which can be loosely defined as material that is not worth processing for the minimal amount of gold that may be in it. The idea is to put topsoil down on the dumps to enable vegetation to grow in it. That vegetation may be planted in the form of creeping salt bush, trees or whatever. Depending on the sort of rainfall there is, those plants can be planted into the dumps.

Mullock dumps are created one layer at a time. When the first layer is completed, the topsoil is put down on the sites. It is pointless having a dump about 50 metres high and then expecting the trucks to tip on topsoil which will go all the way down the sides. It just will not work. It has to be an ongoing process. Of course, if topsoil is not put on from the start, it is impossible because of the height of the dump to put it on at all.

If one waits until the end of the life of the mine to conduct restoration, it may be that the mining company has gone somewhere else and there is no-one responsible to carry out the work immediately. This Bill allows for partial on-going restoration of the mine site and tax deductibility will be available along the line.

The Bill provides some relief in respect of substantiation and fringe benefits tax. This arose out of the famous case involving a Minister. I do not think he signed the logbook every day of the week or every time he moved his car, and though the Commissioner did not disbelieve him, it was considered that the person concerned had not taken full recognition of the law. I think it is worthy of comment that the Commissioner, or whoever helped to draft this Bill, has seen some light. Time and time again we have said in this place that substantiation will get harder and harder, especially under self-assessment.

My next note on this Bill, a note that I wrote some time ago, had to do with provisional tax. No relief is being given in that area. We dealt with this matter on another Bill last night. I am glad Senator McMullan is in the chamber to hear what I am about to tell him. I have always believed that there should be no uplift factor when we are at the bottom of the worst recession we have had for 60 years. But we have a 10 per cent uplift. It has been included, and taxpayers have the right to vary provisional tax. Of course, taxpayers have to be within 10 per cent correct or they will cop a penalty under section 221YDB of the tax Act. Those penalties have been dished out in Western Australia left, right and centre because of what happened last year in the variations.

Yesterday Senator McMullan told the Senate how Treasury got the examination of the Fightback package right. Yet it could not get its figures right on any other Estimates, so last night the Senate had before it the Appropriation Bill (No. 5). The Minister then went on to tell me—and I will give him a chance to apologise—that we have a 10 per cent uplift factor because the Opposition and the Democrats got together—and Senator Kernot may remember this—and forced a 10 per cent uplift.

I would like to remind honourable senators that the amendment the Opposition moved, aided by the Democrats, was that the figure be 10 per cent rather than 12 per cent. If Senator McMullan reads the Hansard he will see it for himself. The argument was whether the regulation showed between 10 per cent to 12 per cent or 10 per cent. We amended that to fix a ceiling of 10 per cent. The Government wants 10 to 12 per cent. Minister McMullan may like to explain why he misled the Senate on that point last night. If he reads the Hansard and the regulations, he will find that that is so. I repeat that the Opposition set it at 10 per cent, whereas the Government wanted it to stay at a figure of 10 to 12 per cent. I am sure the Democrats will have a bit to say about that later. I am inviting Senator McMullan who is now at the table to tell us why, to take the heat off the Government, he made a misleading statement.

Treasury is believed to be right when it comes to examining the Fightback package, but is not expected to be right when it gives us Forward Estimates before appropriations. Taxpayers in calculating provisional tax are expected to be within the category of 10 per cent accuracy. I was also told by the Minister that the power was in the hands of the Commissioner of Taxation. Therefore, I suggest that perhaps the Commissioner be responsible for running Treasury. We might then get some sense injected into this field and be provided with the right sorts of forecasts.

In summary, I believe that this Bill was far too late for the reasons I have already pointed out, especially in bringing into being the measures on the new depreciation schedule. That schedule was not announced in the One Nation package, it was not announced last November, but was announced in the March 1991 statement. Here we are getting the schedule 13 months later. Any plant bought after March 1991 will attract three lots of depreciation. The Government originally said that the depreciation schedules announced in March 1991 would come into action on 1 July 1991. But after pressure was applied by industry and machinery dealers, the Government agreed to go back to 12 March 1991. Any machinery bought at that time will attract three lots of depreciation by the time we are finished. This Bill was very late and parts of it were necessary to fix up sloppy drafting.

I have not got the time to go into much further detail about the depreciation schedules. They will be in operation for only a matter of six months before the new ones come into action. At Question Time Senator Button tells us time and time again how this new depreciation schedule will help industry. As I said last night on another Bill, the only thing the new schedule has done is to cut down the 30-year write-off to seven years. A 30-year write-off was hardly ever felt because, after the first three or four years, inflation took away any benefit one may have enjoyed. With shorter periods of two, three, five and seven years, depreciation remains very much the same.

I believe that the Government had to bring this Bill in to fix up its mistakes. There is one more Bill in line and one more around the corner to fix up further mistakes. If the Government wants to start pinching parts of our Fightback package, it should take the whole lot and put it into action. With that, it might be able to turn Australia around.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991 was the last omnibus taxation Bill to be introduced during 1991. As is the usual practice, this piece of legislation has been held over until the beginning of the Autumn sittings. When enacted, it will become the Tax Laws Amendment Act 1992. The issues in this Bill are numerous and extremely wide-ranging, and it will take me quite a while to deal with them. The legislation is to be referred to a legislative committee after the second reading, so I guess we can expect some amendments to arise from the more detailed consideration that the Bill will receive by that committee.

PARA.TAB: Before considering what we regard to be the major aspects of the Bill, I would like to mention the fringe benefit tax amendments which are proposed. We should commend the Government for proposing these amendments which flow directly from the previous work of this chamber and that of Senator Watson in particular. The question of totally unfair and inflexible substantiation rules—that is, the rules which prescribe the types of records and documentation which must be kept by taxpayers—was thrust into the public debate after the correct, but what was seen as the manifestly unfair, decision in the Evangelist's case. A private senator's Bill was prepared by Senator Watson and was passed with Democrat support. The Government acted quickly to remedy the situation. The Government is now proposing a similar discretion to disregard technical breaches of the fringe benefits tax substantiation provisions. These amendments have the full support of the Democrats.

The major issue to be dealt with in this Bill is the issue of depreciation. The former Prime Minister's industry statement of March 1991 announced proposed changes to the business depreciation regime, and it has taken a year for this matter to finally come before the Senate. The absurdity of this is now compounded by the fact that these rules have already been superseded by the recent economic statement of the new Prime Minister (Mr Keating), but still we press on.

The original announcement proposed to legislate to clarify the meaning of the `effective life of plant'; to permit taxpayers to self-assess the rate of depreciation; to reduce the number of rate classes for depreciation from 18 to seven broad-banded rate classes; to allow taxpayers to pool items within a rate class to simplify the administrative burden of the existing system; and to permit items with a value of less than $300, or with a life of three years or less, to be deductible immediately to reduce the accounting costs for these small items.

The new depreciation arrangements, other than the pooling and broad banding, were to have applied to assets acquired or first held ready for use after 1 July 1991. Broad banding and pooling commenced on 1 July 1991 for all assets except those which are eligible for the previous accelerated depreciation which was axed by Mr Keating whilst he was Treasurer. Perhaps the best summary of these measures was provided in Tim Dodd's article in the Financial Review the next day when he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: More flexibility and simplicity was introduced into tax depreciation in yesterday's Industry Statement, but the significantly accelerated depreciation rates sought by business were not delivered.

Subsequently, industry negotiated with the Tax Office and the Treasury on the details of the proposals. There were some unclear matters, in particular, the question of whether the effective life of a piece of equipment should be determined according to the intentions of the original purchaser or by some more objective criteria.

PARA.TAB: For example, where a company proposes to purchase a photocopier for intensive use over, say, two years and then sell it, the industry interpreted the Government's original statement and the Tax Office's initial explanatory pamphlet on the matter, to be unequivocal. The company could have depreciated the item, using an effective life of two years, and then disposed of it, with any sale proceeds being included in assessable income or used as a balancing charge on a new item of equipment. But the Tax Office decided to delete the reference to the taxpayer, thereby arguing that the objective effective life should be used, thus spreading the depreciation deductions allowable over a longer period and then allowing a balancing claim only at the time the item was sold.

This led to the claim that government officials were undermining the intention of the Government's announcement. Indeed, Senator Watson raised this matter in Estimates committee hearings last year.Finally, in this saga, on 26 September 1991, the then Treasurer, Mr Kerin, released the final details of the effective life arrangements. Business was generally happy with the revised arrangements as they included the option for a taxpayer to depreciate an item of plant on the basis of the taxpayer's circumstance of use.

However, when the legislation was finally released, it was still deficient. The current Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, the fourth to have been involved in the preparation of this Bill—maybe that is some sort of record—had to issue a press release on 25 February 1992 announcing two further amendments, which Senator McMullan will presumably speak to. The purposes of these amendments were, firstly, to clarify that taxpayers may use the Commissioner's advisory rates if they so decide; and, secondly, to clarify a technical change relating to the treatment of second-hand goods.

Mr Kerin also announced that because of representations from the business community the new rates would apply to assets purchased after the industry statement was made—that is, 12 March 1991—but before 1 July 1991, but only in respect of depreciation claims from 1 July 1991. The original announcement also specified that taxpayers who elected to apply self-assessed rates which differed from the Commissioner's advisory rates would have to indicate this choice on the front of their tax return. This requirement was criticised and was reversed by the Government on the condition that relevant documentation as to why a particular depreciation rate was adopted is kept by taxpayers for a possible future audit.

The broad banding arrangements were also modified by allowing a 20 per cent loading on all assets which were not eligible for the former 5 : 3 depreciation regime, and by making the adoption of the broad banding optional, as there were some circumstances where taxpayers could have been disadvantaged because of the administrative effort required for them to comply. Furthermore, the Government also agreed that the $300 immediate expensing limit is to be annually reviewed by government.

At this stage I would like to flag an amendment which I will be moving in the committee stage of this Bill. We see that there is an anomaly in the immediate expensing regime which this amendment of ours is designed to remedy. The decision to grant a legislative basis for all taxpayers regarding immediate expensing is a positive step. We support that initiative. But we think that the Government's proposals fail to take into account the effect of income tax ruling IT 2264 which has been in effect since early 1986.

This ruling, which does not have the force of law but which does govern the practice of the Commissioner, provides a $500, not a $300, limit for immediate expensing of items used by companies, excluding leasing companies, but not by individuals. We see this as an anomaly. We will be moving an amendment to increase the $300 proposed limit to $500. Why should tax law benefit corporate taxpayers relative to individual small business people? Why should big business be additionally favoured over small business? I hope that the Opposition, which always professes concern about the burden of paperwork on small business, will agree to this amendment.

When Mr Kerin announced these measures, it was reported that they were going to cost $100m in 1992-93. Since then, I think he said something to the effect that the new rules could cost far more than the nominal $100m now estimated as the cost to revenue. But we still find the cost depreciation provisions in the financial impact statement in the explanatory memorandum to be $100m. So I ask for clarification. Does there need to be an adjustment of those figures, or did Mr Kerin get it wrong?
At the time these measures were announced, the Government was concerned about their cost. The then Treasurer, Mr Keating, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government does not believe that assets should be written off faster at an even higher budgetary cost.
But less than 12 months later we have the same man completely reversing his position and introducing a further modification to the depreciation regime.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the bias against long term productive investment is to be removed, with a further acceleration of the depreciation of assets with an effective life in excess of five

SPEECH.PARA: years that are acquired on or after 27 February 1992. This reconsideration of the issue arises from the persistent efforts of Senator Button, who established a business taxation review within government last year. This new regime will allow assets with effective lives of 10 and 20 years to be fully depreciated after six and 7 1/2 years respectively.

PARA.TAB: Just to keep the Government's record intact, after the One Nation statement the Treasurer announced further changes to the newly announced regime by way of press release No. 42. Taxpayers will be able to continue to depreciate plant and equipment on a prime cost basis. The rate will be two-thirds the declining balance rate for each of the six effective life asset classes. This will be rounded to the nearest whole number.

The new legislation will allow taxpayers to depreciate assets at rates which are lower than those now allowed, if the taxpayers so choose. So, after all that, let us hope that the Government has finally got it right. But we still think we can point to some long standing problems which need to be addressed.

An anomaly has been drawn to my attention concerning the scope of the depreciation provisions. Only plant or articles, as defined by section 54 of the assessment Act, qualify for depreciation, although other deductions are allowed for other capital expenses, such as tourist accommodation, buildings and some primary production expenditure. The One Nation statement also proposes to extend the types of tourist related structural improvements that can be written off. I mention these just to illustrate that, in our opinion, the existing capital allowances are still deficient in some respects.

The anomaly that I am referring to is the treatment of the expenses of planting fruit trees. Currently, the expenses of planting new orchards are not tax deductible to primary producers. Neither is the expense—which I agree is a capital expense—allowed under any of the capital allowance provisions. So the only tax relief available to an orchardist is a capital loss when the trees have reached the end of their useful life. Even then, no relief from income tax is allowed—only relief from the capital gains tax liability, if one exists.

A further anomaly arises when an existing orchard is purchased by a primary producer. Even though the trees may be fully mature and have a finite production life—that is, their value depreciates—no depreciation is allowable for income tax purposes. Under some circumstances, a capital loss may be allowable when the trees have reached the end of their useful life, but this is only where a separate value can be put on the trees. Again, it is only allowable to offset against a capital gain liability. So, clearly, some anti-avoidance provisions will be necessary to stop the generation of unwarranted deductions by the transfer of legal ownership of a mature orchard whilst the beneficial ownership is unchanged. But we do not think this affects the validity of the issue.

We should ask why a distinction is made between machines, which have a finite useful life, and trees, which also have a finite useful life. The products produced by both are important to this nation. Most people would agree that a competitive taxation regime assists in keeping Australian industries world competitive, be they primary or secondary industries. Currently, fruit tree growers are clearly at a disadvantage. We should do something to redress that. I intend to write to farming bodies about this issue. I expect the National Party to give some interest to this issue when the amendments come before the Senate.

We are constantly told that simplification in the taxation area is high on the Government's agenda. This is a classic example of a much greater complexity being introduced because of inadequate and fragmented policy. I just hope that this new regime will be left to operate without further changes once the additional measures, just announced by the Prime Minister, and maybe the suggestions I have made, come into force.

Various other matters are contained in this Bill. There is the belated enactment of some balancing adjustment roll-over relief provisions which were supposedly announced on 8 December 1990. Senator Watson has already pointed out that this was not the case. I am aware that an extraordinary and tragic event caused the confusion but, when announcing prospective legislative intent, the Government must be as flawless as possible. In this case it was not. These provisions ensure that the depreciation system and the capital gains tax regime are complementary. Obviously, the Democrats do not oppose that.

Still in the area of depreciation, there are also some anti-avoidance measures which correct a technical deficiency in the existing law. Ordinarily, where assets are sold for an amount in excess of their written down value, that excess is taxable as income. However, assets can be disposed of to a related company and then sold off, thereby realising the gain and not having to pay capital gains tax, nor having the proceeds treated as a recoupment of prior depreciation claims. This anomaly is addressed in the legislation before us. It appears that this is the provision which Senator Panizza, in his speech, claimed is redundant because of the capital gains tax. I am sure that Senator McMullan will clarify that as well.

I am advised that there is a loophole because a related company is not liable to pay any tax on depreciation recoupment where an asset is sold for more than its depreciated value. It is not liable to capital gains tax because, for the purposes of the capital gains tax, the asset is deemed to have been acquired by the related company at market price. So when this is then sold, no capital gains tax liability arises. This is the loophole which is addressed by the amendment. I submit that such an arrangement should constitute a scheme for the purposes of part 4A of the assessment Act. Perhaps Senator McMullan could explain why, instead of more legislation being introduced, the Commissioner could not have pursued that line to deal with these arrangements.

There are also two proposals to amend capital gains tax provisions. Firstly, an anti-avoidance measure is contained in clause 51 of the Bill. This provision is aimed at ensuring that the legislation operates as originally intended. Unwarranted benefits will accrue to some taxpayers if this anomaly is allowed to continue, so the Democrats will support this measure. The second capital gains tax measure is a simple administrative one which substitutes the responsibility for publishing the indexation factors from the Treasurer to the Commissioner.

Another matter covered by the Bill is deductibility of mine site rehabilitation expenses. The industry has raised some technical questions which the Government is clarifying with these amendments. The Democrats do not oppose the alteration of the law to allow a deduction for rehabilitation expenses which are incurred by the mining company whilst mining operations are still proceeding. Indeed, this would tend to indicate an immediate rehabilitation plan is being implemented by the mine operator, which would generally be a good thing.

However, there is ambiguity in the policy proposal in the Bill with respect to the allowance of deductions for expenses for partial site restoration. The Democrats believe that any mine site must be fully restored after it is exploited. Consequently, any proposal which grants tax relief to partial or inadequate rehabilitation is bad public policy and should be opposed. That is not to say that we are opposed to allowing a deduction for partial rehabilitation as it occurs as long as the total plan is to completely rehabilitate the site.

However, the proposed amendment—clause 43 of the Bill—specifically states that a deduction is to be granted even if the taxpayer has no intention of completing the restoration. What sort of policy is this for a Government which is supposed to be committed to sustainable development? The Government is saying, `Well, you go ahead and mine an area and if you don't want to return it to the same condition, or even a reasonable approximation of the original condition, then that's fine—you do what you want and we'll give you a tax deduction for it'. The Democrats oppose this approach.

The ESD working group on mining issued its final report in November 1991. The Government has still not responded to any of these reports. The proposal in this Bill seems to be totally inconsistent with the recommendations of the report. I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard recommendations 31 to 35 of the report of the ESD working group on mining which deal specifically with mine site rehabilitation.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendation 31—that:

(a)companies be required to lodge security bonds or similar financial instruments to ensure that the cost of rehabilitation of mine sites can be met by the miner rather than through public funding; and

(b)where a rehabilitation bond applies, whether provided in cash or as a guarantee, it be linked to scientifically testable objectives for successful rehabilitation which will largely determine when a lessee's responsibilities are discharged and the lease can be relinquished. Such criteria might be set either in physical terms, such as the structure and composition of plant or animal communities, or measurable characteristics of terrain, soil, hydrology and water quality and aesthetics.

Recommendation 32—that the security bond system allow a reduction where a high level of performance has been established, with provision for review of the bond level with change of ownership of the tenement.
Recommendation 33—that all of the arrangements regarding rehabilitation bonds, rehabilitation plans and the basis on which they were determined be available for public scrutiny.
Recommendation 34—that the project planning procedures and guiding principles of regulatory authorities, recognise and control those circumstances where some delay in rehabilitation may occur.
Recommendation 35—that governments not fully release security bonds until they are satisfied that mining sites have been rehabilitated to a maintenance-free status.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, the proposition being put forward by the Government is totally inconsistent with the theme of ecologically sustainable development, which must involve full mine site rehabilitation. The Democrats will be moving an amendment to remove clause 43 from the Bill.

PARA.TAB: There are numerous other matters in this Bill. There are some technical changes to the foreign source income provisions and to the Australia-Fiji double tax treaty. Perhaps the most alarming measure is another anti-avoidance amendment which concerns the tax treatment of foreign exchange gains and losses. The explanatory memorandum summarises the proposal as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments will ensure that a deduction for a foreign exchange loss of a capital nature on a contract will be reduced by a gain on an underlying, hedging of other contract if that gain is not included in assessable income.

We should ask why this obvious loophole was not specifically dealt with at the time the Government decided to extend the concession of allowing exchange rate losses on capital account to be treated in the same manner as exchange rate losses on revenue account. How much money has this particular oversight cost the Australian community?

PARA.TAB: The Bill also provides some technical and anti-avoidance amendments to the research and development deduction provisions and further modifications to the tax file number system. But I will not go into those because I want to comment on two remaining areas covered by the legislation.

Firstly, the issue of tax avoidance and trading stock has arisen again. The trading stock provisions were enormously abused during the golden age of tax avoidance, the sixties and seventies. The judgments by the Barwick High Court in the Curran and Wesfarmers cases, to name but two, were both legendary and, I would argue, disgraceful. Although those and other decisions could also be attributed to the philosophy of the judiciary at the time, the recent decision in the Raymor case shows that there are still problems in the income tax legislation in this area.

An income tax deduction is properly allowable when a taxpayer purchases trading stock. However, there must be a reversal of this deduction in respect of unsold stock at the end of the year, otherwise businesses could definitely defer paying any income tax by purchasing large amounts of trading stock at the end of every financial year. The tax law has long recognised this necessity to match income and expenses, and section 28 of the assessment Act attempts to do this.

Unfortunately, section 28 refers to stock on hand at the close of the year. It is possible, in certain circumstances, to circumvent the intention of section 28. Examples are forward purchase contracts of goods and, in some circumstances, goods in transit. This Bill proposes to remedy this anomaly by altering the general deduction provision to bring it into line with the wording in section 28. It is such a pity that people seek to find these loopholes and avoid them. Nevertheless, that is the way people operate and, consequently, we are always catching up. The Australian Democrats support this overdue reform.

The second matter is the question of the availability of dividend rebates. The Bill provides a retrospective amendment back to 1976 to overcome the decision in the Patcorp case. This is a very strange situation because the Commission adopted as practice the allowing of dividend rebates as contemplated in this Bill.

The matter was forgotten until the Commissioner decided to apply the law, not his usual practice, to the Adelaide Steamship group of companies. We then had the ironic role reversal of very sophisticated taxpayers arguing that the Commissioner should not apply the law and the Commissioner reversing his usual practice. The amendment is retrospective but does not apply to assessments already made. Therefore, this decision does not aid any taxpayer against whom the Commissioner has already applied the law.

I would like to finish this lengthy explanation by paying credit to the Taxation Office officials for producing an excellent, user-friendly explanatory memorandum. The Tax Office's explanatory memorandums are always of a very high standard and this Bill continues that tradition.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991POULTRY INDUSTRY ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 February, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 is an omnibus Bill that will make a number of amendments relating to unauthorised receipt of goods and services by authorised officers under the Meat Inspection Act 1983; the eligibility of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory to receive assistance under the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Act 1978; and the corporate and annual operational plan requirements of the Australian Wheat Board under the Wheat Marketing Act 1989.

PARA.TAB: Under the amendments to the Meat Inspection Act of 1983, the definition of authorised officer will be changed to allow the Secretary only to appoint such officers. `Authorised officer' is classified in subsection 3(1) of the Act to mean an officer of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy or a person appointed under section 32 of the Act to be an authorised officer.

Section 32 of the Act provides that the Secretary of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy may appoint a person, or a person in a class of persons, to be an authorised officer or authorised officers. Authorised officers have a number of powers under the Act, including entering a prescribed premise, inspecting or examining premises, a vehicle, ship, aircraft, matter or thing or taking extracts from or making copies of any documents.

Under these amendments it will be an offence for an authorised officer to receive goods or services from the owner of prescribed premises or employees or agents of such an owner without approval in writing from the Secretary to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. The penalty, which is in line with current criminal law policy, will omit monetary penalty where terms of imprisonment are provided for. In the case of this provision it is 12 months.

With regard to the amendments to the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Act of 1978, water resource projects are administered by the States and Territories. The Commonwealth is involved by way of providing funds to the States and the Northern Territory for water projects and in respect of research conducted by the CSIRO.

The annual level of financial assistance for projects under the Act is determined each year in the Budget. The allocation of funds to specific projects and subprograms takes account of the States' priorities for funding and the extent to which the activities progress the Commonwealth's objectives.

The scheme of assistance provided by the Act has been the subject of a recent audit by the Australian Audit Office. It was found by the Australian Audit Office that the Act and related agreements with the States provided sufficient authority for payments made under the scheme and that adequate processes for allocation and control of expenditure and monitoring of performance for individual projects were in operation.

However, the Australian Audit Office noted that the objectives of the scheme as contained in guidelines issued by the Department do not provide a basis for quantifiable measures to be applied to program outcomes. Acquittal of program expenditures by the senior executive officer of the State organisation or an approved body receiving the funds will now be permitted. The Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory will be made eligible to receive assistance under the Act.

With regard to the amendments to the Wheat Marketing Act of 1989, the date by which the Australian Wheat Board must submit its corporate plan to the Minister will be altered to 1 September. In addition, the annual operating plans will need to be prepared by 1 October and the requirement for the Minister to approve the annual operating plans will be removed in line with recommendations of the Davis review of statutory marketing authorities. The Liberal and National parties will be supporting these various amendments.

The Poultry Industry Assistance Amendment Bill will amend the Poultry Industry Assistance Act 1965 to allow the Commonwealth to recover costs incurred in collecting outstanding levies from 11 New South Wales egg producers who owe $1.7m. The Poultry Industry Assistance Act 1965, the Poultry Industry Levy Act 1965 and the Poultry Industry Levy Collection Act 1965 gave effect to a hen levy scheme which is currently being wound up.

The Poultry Industry Levy Act 1965 imposed a levy on hens over six months of age. The levy was applied on a prescribed day each fortnight at a maximum rate of levy per hen of $2 per annum. The levy ceased operation on 30 June 1987. However, the Poultry Levy Collection Act and the principal Act continue to operate to allow the collection of late payments and the recovery of outstanding debts.

The principal Act established the Poultry Industry Trust Fund, known as `the Fund', into which an appropriation of Commonwealth funding equates the amount collected by way of levy under the Poultry Industry Levy Collection Act of 1965. The principal Act also provides for the disbursement of moneys in the fund for assistance to the poultry industry and the making of arrangements by the Minister for loans to the State egg boards.

At 30 June 1990, the balance in the fund totalled $567,228. In regard to the Poultry Industry Assistance Act 1965, in the annual report for 1989-90 it is reported that $1.62m in levies and penalty interest remained unpaid at 30 June 1990. This amount is essentially owed by producers in New South Wales and is the subject of legal actions of recovery.

The industry would like to wind up the Poultry Industry Trust Fund as soon as possible, but this cannot happen until the courts decide whether this money is recoverable. In the meantime, the New South Wales Egg Marketing Corporation, which used to collect the fees from that State on behalf of the Commonwealth, has been terminated, leaving the responsibility of collecting the money to the Commonwealth.

The Poultry Assistance Act allows the Minister to reimburse the States from the Trust Fund the cost incurred in the collection of levies, but not the Commonwealth. It is therefore necessary to amend the Act to allow these costs to be paid from the Trust Fund.

It is a common feature of Commonwealth levy and charge legislation to provide for the recovery of Commonwealth costs associated with the collection and disbursement of funds raised through levies and charges. It should be noted that the principal Act of this legislation does not provide for the recovery by the Commonwealth of expenses associated with the hen levy.

Prior to the winding up of the hen levy scheme, responsibility for the collection of levies rested with the State egg boards. Costs incurred by the State egg boards were reimbursed from the Fund. Any money recovered by the courts, together with the balance of the account minus any costs incurred in the collection of funds, will be transferred into the research and development funds. Again, I indicate that the Liberal and National parties support this legislation.

It is important to recognise that primary industries are going through very difficult seasonal and economic circumstances in Australia at the moment. We know that the recession, which has been induced by the Government, has not yet reached the pits of how it is certainly going to affect this important primary industry economy. The rural crisis is extremely real. It is impacting on all sectors of primary industry.

Farm commodity prices and incomes have fallen sharply. There has been a remarkable fall in real capital expenditure and farm debt servicing is at a record high. This means that the people who are continuing to derive their incomes, their livelihoods and their associated employment in the primary industries are certainly feeling the effect and are looking to government for substantial improvement of their circumstances. We would on another occasion welcome a full-blown debate on the circumstances of primary industry today. That would be welcome on any day. But on this occasion, I indicate our support for this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also will be supporting the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991. Like Senator Tambling, I will not use this as an excuse to enter a full-blown debate about the status of the rural economy or the Government's treatment of the primary industries. However, I will direct some remarks to matters that are associated with this legislation.

PARA.TAB: While indicating support for the meat inspection and poultry aspects of the legislation—and in particular, for that part of the legislation which deals with our natural water resources and the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Act 1978—I would like to take the opportunity to skirt the issue of our water resources.

We are told that the amendments to the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Act 1978 are designed to improve the efficiency of its administration in three respects. Quite understandably, there is general support for simplifying the administration by placing the requirements of the Act under the responsibility of one Minister. This seems eminently logical. It also seems logical to make the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory eligible to receive assistance under the Act. But that leads me to what seems to be one of the fundamental problems in the administration of our inland waters in particular. It seems to me that a huge component of our water problems is the very fact that our States and Territories are self-governing and have different policies, attitudes and strategies for properly managing our water resources.

That situation is extremely well illustrated by the recent problems we have had with the Murray-Darling catchment and the algal bloom. The responsibility to act on that problem was a matter of some discussion and some inertia in terms of dealing with the problem. Any government really, whether State, Territory or Federal, which recognises the urgency of correctly managing our water resources, might well do a little more than dissipate the legislative opportunity or at least the Executive opportunity to deal with water problems. It would probably come up with strategies to recognise the need—as was expressed by Dr Mike Synnot of Curtin University—to establish a national water quality standard to ensure the quality of our water supply as well as the quantity. Such a strategy would at least recognise the different requirements of our water users.

Immediately apparent to anybody who has ever been involved with local government—I just recently finished my involvement with it—is that, in most of our cities, as those who are responsible for administering the supply of reticulated water would be well aware, usually less than 5 per cent of the water which is supplied for domestic use needs to be of potable water quality. That which is used for flushing toilets, watering gardens, washing cars and myriad other uses has no requirement to be of a potable, drinking, cooking standard. The immense cost to our community of supplying that reticulated water to such a standard is really something we should be addressing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then you're going to have double reticulation.

—I will accept Senator Panizza's interjection. No, not necessarily double reticulation. But Senator Panizza would surely be familiar with the situation that obtains in many of our country towns in Australia whereby water that is used for drinking is, in fact, either tank water or provided from another source, even carted water; whereas the reticulated water is seldom fit for drinking—and perhaps that is a blessing because it is then not wasted. I would not suggest that the situation is one which we should repeat in our capital cities, but the alternatives are there and should be considered.

PARA.TAB: To supply 95 per cent of our water at a potable standard to be flushed down the toilet or to be flung at the prized possessions of people in their driveways is a pretty inefficient way to run the water resources of the country. As a quick example, one with which I am familiar, in our second driest capital city—that is Hobart—out of a budget of something less than $50m, the Hobart City Council spends up to $5m on the supply of reticulated water. That is the cost involved in just purchasing it from the Hobart Metropolitan Water Board; it does not cover the cost of repairs, maintenance and new extensions. So it is a matter of some considerable importance.

Any government which recognised the need to become involved in formulating a strategy to consider properly our water supply in Australia, would also recognise the characteristics of water supply in Australia, including the fact that much of our inland rural land depends upon using water which has already been used upstream. Consequently, the ecological interrelationship of water, soil, flora and fauna would be recognised. Because of that, we would need to encourage State and local governments to undertake the necessary capital works for the standardisation of quality regulation and any other measures that are necessary to complement the national strategies. I am not suggesting that nobody has ever thought of this. I am not suggesting for one moment that this is being ignored by the Federal Government or our State and regional governments. But what I am suggesting is that we need to bring on that debate a little more quickly in this national forum.

I was disappointed with the contribution that Mr Lloyd made when this Bill was receiving its second reading in the lower House. A considerable part of Mr Lloyd's contribution was to gloss over—and I say that advisedly, not in the pejorative sense; I think it is an accurate description of what was being done—the problems associated with water supply in the Murray-Darling Basin. I quote in part from his speech. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: One has to note that at the time of the outbreak—
speaking of the algal bloom outbreak last summer—
there was a drought and dry weather exacerbates the likelihood of algal outbreaks because the river drops to lower level . . .

True. That does not remove in any way the alarm experienced by those who rely for their livelihood on that river upon seeing that they had absolutely no capacity to deal with the problem themselves. When they turned to any authority that may have been able to do something about it, they found a confusion of authorities and, as I indicated before, a paralysis which discouraged effective and efficient reaction—not that there was anything much that any of the authorities could do in the immediate sense. It was the advent of well-timed rains which actually resolved the problem. The release of water to encourage flow from dams upstream was an opportunity which had been reduced by the very fact that there was a drought. So it is a problem which should not be glossed over.

PARA.TAB: Also in Mr Lloyd's contribution in the lower House was a suggestion that agricultural producers on the Darling really did not use a lot of fertiliser; that the towns located on the Darling, which had sewerage plants releasing their product into the Murray or the Darling, were not really to blame and that industries also had outputs into this area. I think it was a sort of collection of apologies and excuses rather than an encouragement—as it should be and as I would like my contribution today to be seen as—for people, for authorities and for anybody who has any capacity to make any decisions at all with regard to our Murray-Darling Basin, to find a reason to treat this matter seriously and to recognise the importance of this huge natural Australian resource.

At least the CSIRO, I am pleased to say, has recently embarked upon a research program to investigate social justice in water allocation. The study locations are Perth; Lake Hume and the Murray River to Echuca; and the South Esk catchment in Tasmania. The CSIRO team will survey a number of people who are interested in access to water for particular uses in each of the three study locations. It will try to find a process which considers all points of view, minimises conflict and is as fair as possible. That at least is a recognition of the fact that in Australia, water—its use and allocation—is particularly important.

I would like to think that because of the small step the Government is taking in this legislation, it may take the opportunity to recognise how important it is to deal properly with our water and take into consideration the efforts of many Australians who have for decades taken pains to illustrate how important it is. A wonderful contributor to our water management skills has been mentioned in this place before, the famous Australian Ernest Jackson, who is known as Ernest `Watershed' Jackson. He is typical of a number of Australian pioneers in the proper management of our ecological resources, and someone whose contribution should be given much more credibility than the contributions made by so many people which gloss over the urgency of this problem.

I hope that this legislation at least takes a small step along the way towards recognising what a significant problem we have. The Australian Democrats will be supporting the other components of the legislation. I do not see any need to make any other comment about those, because their need for quick enactment is self-evident.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 deals with amendments to four Acts. It amends the Meat Inspection Act 1983, the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Act 1978, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 and the Wheat Marketing Act 1989. I wish to confine my remarks to the Wheat Marketing Act 1989.

PARA.TAB: This Act allows the Australian Wheat Board to delay the submission of its corporate plan to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy until 1 September, which is closer to the Australian Wheat Board's financial year, which commences on 1 October and finishes on 30 September of each year. This is a very sensible financial year for the Australian wheat industry. The amendment will also allow for the Australian Wheat Board's operational plan to be in the hands of the Minister until 1 October and will line up with that financial year. These measures are necessary and will not generate much debate in this place.

In the few moments I have left to me between now and 6 o'clock, I wish to make a few remarks concerning the state of primary industries in Australia at the present moment. At this time of the Wills by-election there is consideration for other industries and I wonder where primary industries are headed.

Before I come to that, I wish to remind everyone that next Thursday is Wool Day in Australia. This has been ably put together by my colleague Mr Wilson Tuckey, the honourable member for O'Connor in the other place, assisted by the honourable member for Stirling and Deputy Speaker, Mr Ronald Edwards. I am sure that the Australian wool industry is coming out of its downturn. I know there is a long way to go in the wool industry, but I can see light at the end of the tunnel. The wool display and auction taking place in the Great Hall is a good exhibition and will certainly show to Canberra and the rest of Australia the importance of wool to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you get the red socks?

—Yes, that is right. It is a pity that when this Parliament House was opened in 1988 the Australian Wool Corporation did not take up the invitation to put on a fashion parade. It does this very well throughout Australia—working in shearing sheds and all over the place—but ignored this opportunity. It shows what the Wool Corporation's priorities were at the time.

PARA.TAB: Primary industry is going through a tough period. The prices are bad enough without this Government's economic mismanagement. During the last planting year wheat attracted low prices, but fortunately they have improved out of sight. We were expecting $120 a tonne when we planted the latest crop in 1991-92, but we finished up with approximately $180 a tonne. That has turned around the wheat industry very successfully. The price of wool is starting to creep up, even though it has a long way to go. Although the market indicator has reduced by some 75 cents a kilo in the last six weeks, hopefully the price is holding, judging by the trend shown at the end of last week.

In the last couple of days we have heard a lot about tariff reform and reforms in different industries. Unfortunately, the Government looked firstly at primary industries, then at secondary industries and thirdly at the transport industries to match those reforms. These reforms are not forthcoming, although every day Senator Collins espouses waterfront reforms in the Senate. There may have been reforms on the waterfront, but any savings are certainly not flowing through to the people who use the waterfront, that is, the importers and exporters. Ask them. In the last 12 months the cost of getting containers or other produce across the wharves in Sydney and Melbourne has increased by 20 per cent. There have been none of the savings on the waterfront that there have been in primary industries.

During Question Time we got a lecture from Senator Button on the lack of tariff reform by the Fraser Government. He outlined what this Government has been doing, until three days ago, concerning tariff reform. That was until the Wills by-election and Prime Minister Keating has certainly changed his direction on tariffs. Senator Button said that the Government was cutting tariff protection down and down. Yet, last December he chose to agree without any debate in this place—and it will be debated before very long—to slap a $12,000 tariff on imported used cars, even though a company to import second-hand Mazda 626 motor vehicles is ready to be set up in order to meet the ADR. There will be quite a lot of debate on that $12,000 tariff.

Yet the Government has always said—and I agree—that the pineapple growers of Queensland, the banana growers, the pea growers, et cetera cannot have tariffs and must compete with the rest of the world. It said that the dairy industry also had to stand on its own feet and compete. We have had to put up with strong competition from New Zealand under the closer economic relations guidelines. Primary industries have accepted that the world of tariffs has passed them by, but it is certainly not extending to the rest of the industries. I am very disappointed that Senator Button has agreed to that $12,000 tariff. If there is to be reform, it should be for all Australians so that primary industries can compete with other industries in Australia and the rest of the world.

We must move towards a better economic climate for primary industry. We have been told that interest rates have come down considerably in the last 12 months. That may have happened in certain areas, but when it comes to farmers borrowing money, lower interest rates have not been quite so forthcoming. As we are to adjourn at 6 p.m., I will conclude my remarks at this point.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 February 1992.

PARA.TAB: (1) When was the discussion paper on Remote Area Allowance by the North Australia Development Unit (Social Security) completed and made available to the department.
(2) What measures have been undertaken by the department to address the concerns identified that there is no uniform criterion by which eligibility for Remote Area Allowance can be determined.

(3) What is the department's response to the following recommendations (a) amend the existing policy and legislation to make physical presence of Tax Zone A as the only criterion for receipt of Remote Area Allowance; (b) extend the payment of Remote Area Allowance to clients physically present in Tax Special Zone B. Introduce a discretionary test similar to taxation legislation for people resident near Zone boundaries; and (c) Social Security apply pressure to review and re-establish the basis for Tax Zones, district and remote allowances and Remote Area Allowance. Ensure that Social Security is represented on any working party, task force or inquiry involved in reviews.
(4) What budget initiatives have been made by the department in response to the recommendations.

(5) What initiatives has the department taken to review the present Tax Zone System, through investigation of costs in each zone, expenditure patterns of people within those zones and regional variations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The North Australia Development Unit was a part of the Department of Social Security at the time the discussion paper was completed in August 1989.
(2) There is a uniform criterion for Remote Area Allowance under the Social Security Act. In broad terms, this is that a person:
is a recipient of one of a range of pensions and allowances under the Social Security Act; and
the person's usual place of residence is in the remote area and the person is physically present in the remote area.
So that payment is not affected by short absences from the remote area, a person is taken to be present in the remote area for up to the first eight weeks of an absence from the remote area.
(3) (a) The removal of "usual residence" from the criteria for payment would make visitors and holiday makers on pensions or allowances eligible for payment. This is not the intention of the payment.
The NADU recommendation also would effectively remove the legislative provision covering payment for short absences.
(b) Remote Area Allowance has been extended by the Government to those resident in Special Zone B.

Places determined by the Commissioner for Taxation, under his discretionary powers under Section 79A(3E) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, as ones to be treated as being in Special Zone B attract Remote Area Allowance.
(c) The then Prime Minister announced a review of tax zone rebates and associated social security arrangements in December 1989. The Department of Social Security was involved in that review.

(4) In the 1990-91 Budget the Government announced significant changes to Tax Zone Rebates and Remote Area Allowances. It reviewed boundaries and brought Special Zone B within the Remote Area Allowance arrangements.

(5) The Department of Social Security is not responsible for the Tax Zone System. The Department has not participated in a systematic review of the Tax Zone System since the 1990 review initiated by the then Prime Minister in December 1989.

(8) Does the department intend to change its policy in this regard.
(9) How does the department inform or advise eligible recipients' both existing and non-existing clients, of benefits that they may be eligible for, particularly in rural/remote areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) This report was completed and made available to the department in November 1989.
(2)(a) and (b) No. A good deal of action has been taken as is shown in the following answers.

(3) The Department has not been involved in research undertaken by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services on this issue. However, one of the key objectives of the Office of Northern Development within the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet is closer consultation and co-ordination of Commonwealth Department research affecting people in rural and remote areas.

(4) Consultation between the two Departments at the Regional Office level occurs regularly on a number of issues, many of which would impact on women in remote and rural areas. (5) The Department's Support Network for Aboriginal Parents Program (SNAP) established in 1989-90 has a key role in identifying access problems experienced by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women in remote and rural areas and developing strategies to assist them.

In addition, the Department has implemented the majority of the recommendations of an audit conducted by the Australian National Audit Office concerning the valuation of real estate including rural property.

(7) The Department does not rely entirely on electronic services to contact clients. Mail is still used to obtain the necessary verification to establish client entitlement. This is supplemented by the use of visiting services, Remote Visiting Teams and Aboriginal Liaison Officers who conduct frequent visits to remote locations to minimise delays in assessment procedures.

(8) As part of its strategy to improve client service delivery, the Department will be establishing a network of Teleservice Centres. In addition to handling general queries concerning social security payments, Teleservice Centre staff will be able to process simple transactions such as changing bank accounts which previously required notification by mail or by visiting a Regional Office. This will be of particular benefit to people in rural and remote areas.
(9) The Department conducts an extensive information service for people in rural and remote areas, using a variety of media including posters, pamphlets and video material.

Information dissemination is also provided through its field network of programs such as Community Agents, Aboriginal Liaison officers and Remote Visiting Teams, as well as through contact with State and local Government welfare agencies. Community bodies are also a link in the process.
In addition to its own activities, the Department participates with other Commonwealth agencies in the Australian Country Information Service run by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 26 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Office of the Status of Women seen the report by the North Australia Development Unit (Social Security) entitled Remote Rural Women's Access to Social Security.
(2) Has the Office made a response in relation to this report and can it be made available to the Senate.
(3) Has the Office conducted any of its own studies on the effects of Social Security payments on women living in rural/remote Australia: if so, can these be provided to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) The Office of the Status of Women (OSW) has not responded to this discussion paper.

The aim of the paper was to stimulate discussion on the access of rural women to social security benefits, and to canvass possible further research options. The paper was not intended as a policy document requiring a formal response.

(3) Whilst the Office of the Status of Women has not specifically conducted studies on the effects of Social Security payments on women living in rural/ remote Australia the following 2 reports undertaken by OSW are relevant.

In 1985 OSW commissioned a national survey—What Women Think—which explored the family budgeting patterns of women with dependant children. Rural and provincial women as well as urban women were included in the sample. The findings of the survey related to financial dependency and the awareness and use of Government support by women generally.

In 1986 OSW in association with the Country Women's Association of Australia conducted a rural women's survey. The Report, Life has never been easy was launched in 1988. This report asked rural women to identify their most critical problems. A broad range of concerns were identified including social issues, financial or economic issues, essential services, education and employment issues.

A third report, Paying the Price for Sugar and Spice, was commissioned in 1983 by the National Women's Advisory Council (an advisory body to Government) and was published in 1985. The report was designed to collect material on the background, circumstances and prospects of women experiencing poverty as recipients of pensions or benefits. The detailed recommendations were wide ranging and address social security issues relevant to women experiencing poverty, but did not refer to women living in rural and remote areas as a separate group.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Conference on Environment and Development

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 26 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the Prime Minister be attending the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development conference to be held in Brazil in 1992; if so, will he be accompanied by any other Ministers, staff members of Government officials.

(2) Has the Government discussed arrangements for any other organisation, environment or business, to attend the conference. (3) What are the full estimated costs of attending the conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Privacy Policy

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 2 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the privacy policy of the Department of Social Security.
(2) What percentage of in-service training time is allocated to Social Security's staff for the purpose of understanding their responsibilities under privacy legislation.
(3) How many people have lost their Social Security benefits in the last twelve months.
(4) What were the reasons for cancellation of benefits.
(5) How many AIDEX protesters were interviewed by Social Security staff after November 1991.
(6) Who authorised contact with Federal Police to gain private information about people exercising their democratic rights.
(7) Does the department regularly liaise with the Federal Police when Social Security beneficiaries are involved in other protest action.
(8) Does the department have information about Australia's obligations under the United Nations' Convention on Civil and Political Rights; if so, how is this disseminated in staff training.
(9) Has the department breached the United Nations' Convention by singling out protesters for `special reviews'.
(10) What are the procedures to be followed by staff if an allegation is made against a Social Security recipient.
(11) How many allegations are required for staff to respond and what protection is there for recipients to fully respond to allegations.
(12) Have AIDEX protesters been kept informed about their entitlements since the `special reviews' and have any entitlements been cancelled as a result of those reviews.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department's policy is to follow the information privacy principles in the Privacy Act 1988 and to ensure that staff know about and comply with them and the confidentiality provisions in the Social Security Act 1991, the secrecy provisions in the Crimes Act 1914 and relevant Public Service Regulations.

(2) A training package has been developed for privacy training for all staff. Privacy issues are also covered in other training modules and are an important element of many other technical training programs for regional office staff.

Privacy is an integral part of induction training for all recruits and training for public contact staff. The Privacy Contact officers in the Department also carry out some on-going training and information sessions on privacy issues.
The integration of privacy issues within many training modules means precise identification of the staff time involved is not possible.
(3) 82,221 payments were cancelled in the last twelve months as a result of departmentally initiated review activity. Some people may have been subject to more than one cancellation.
(4) The main reasons for cancellation of various payments were:
failure to lodge a review or continuation form
returned to work
not at address
reconciliation with spouse (Sole Parents Pension)
failure to attend interview
living in a marriage-like relationship (Sole Parents Pension)
fit for work

(5) Since the Department does not know the names of most of the AIDEX protesters it is not possible to answer the question. Of those known to have participated in the protest, 37 have been interviewed or interviews have been attempted. At this stage it is intended to interview one other person. Some protesters who were social security recipients voluntarily relinquished payments. This seems to have occurred as part of the ordinary course of events where people on Job Search Allowance obtain work or undertake studies.

(6) The Secretary of the Department asked the Privacy, Fraud and Control Division if names and addresses of those arrested could be obtained. This was against the background that one of the AIDEX protesters publicly suggested that he, and, by implication, other protesters were engaged regularly in protest activities rather than seeking employment.

An approach to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) in writing was made by the AFP liaison officer in the Area South-West Office in NSW, asking if names and addresses could be provided. This followed discussions between the Privacy, Fraud and Control Division in the Department's National Administration and the AFP liaison officer. The approach was made as an initial step in reviewing the continuing eligibility for Social Security payments. Information Privacy Principle 11 permits disclosure of information where it is reasonably necessary for the protection of the public revenue.

(7) There is no regular liaison because the Department is not concerned with involvement in protest action per se. However, involvement in some protest actions or other activities can be of a duration or type which is incompatible with continuing eligibility for social security payments.

(8) The Department has information about Australia's obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR). The key obligation for Departmental staff concerns the right to privacy. Relevant information is disseminated in staff training as outlined in (2) above.

(9) The reviews were conducted following allegations that AIDEX demonstrators might not be eligible for social security payments. It is the Department's general policy to conduct reviews where there are allegations of non-eligibility for social security payments and the policy was applied in this case. The demonstrators were not treated any differently from other persons about whom allegations are made. On this basis the reviews do not contravene Australia's obligations under the ICCPR. This has been confirmed by the Attorney-General's Department.
(10) The nature of review depends on the nature of the allegation and the information supplied.
It can include verification of information with third parties (eg seeking income details from an employer).
In all but unusual cases, there is an interview with the recipient.
(11) There is no minimum number of allegations prescribed in the way suggested.
Where any allegation has sufficient details to enable follow up and is obviously not ill founded or made in bad faith, a review will be conducted.
This is necessary to maintain public confidence in the integrity of the Social Security system.

As indicated above, in all but unusual cases (eg the person is overseas or major fraud could be involved) the client concerned will be interviewed by Department of Social Security staff and given the opportunity to comment on the matters raised.
The Department is conscious that, while cases must be adequately reviewed, many public denunciations prove to be unfounded and care is needed in undertaking reviews.

If any decision affecting payment is made there are extensive rights of appeal on the merits available (Authorised Review Officers, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal).
There are also avenues of complaint about the manner in which the Department has acted (in particular to the Ombudsman and the Privacy Commissioner).
(12) Some reviews are still in progress.
At this stage payments to four of the people concerned have been stopped.
In cases where the review has concluded that payments should be continued, the recipients are being treated in the same way as other recipients.
A final point is that, in a small number of cases, reviews were, or are, being conducted independently of the action referred to in this question and answer.
